A correspondent of Mary Russell Mitford in 1835. Forename unknown. Likely the mother of Miss Yates. Dates unknown.

Actor who performed at Covent Garden and Drury Lane between 1807 and 1832. Acted under Mr. Young. Rival of Kean. Known for his Hamlet. Written about by Washington Irving. His son wrote a memoir of him in 1871.
Clergyman and poet, author of Night-Thoughts, important promulgator of the late-eighteenth century Graveyard School of poetry.
Medical doctor from Reading. Dates unknown.

Actor who appeared in Rienzi at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1828. Acted under Mr. Younge. Forename unknown. Dates unknown. Not identical with well-known lead actor Charles Mayne Young, who also appeared in the play.
Prebendary of Durham and scholar of Izaak Walton. Mitford read his Memoirs of the Life and Writings of Sir Philip Sidney.

org.note: Attendants and group of other unnamed characters in Rienzi.
The Balfours of Burley are a family of characters in Walter Scott’s Old Mortality .
The blacksmith, a character introduced in the first sketch of Our Village , is said to have eight children.
Group of unnamed bricklayers who work for the whimsical man who renovates his house in Our Village.
Group of unnamed children in Our Village.
Characters who work for the whimsical wealthy man who renovates his house in Our Village.
Group of unnamed characters who work for the whimsical wealthy man who renovates his house in Our Village.
Group of unnamed characters who make up the Chorus in Rienzi.
Group of unnamed characters who are citizens of Rome in Rienzi.
Fictional version of the historical Council of Tenas represented in Mitford's play Foscari.

Characters who appear in several Our Village stories. The narrator mentions her partiality for country boys, particularly in the title sketch, as well as Frost and Thaw, The Hard Summer and A Country Cricket Match. These boys include Jack Rapley,Joe Kirby, Jem Eusden.
Characters who appear in the Our Village stories A Country Cricket Match and The Hard Summer.
Group of unnamed characters mentioned in the first sketch of Our Village . The curate's family is said to live in another town, four miles away.
Unnamed group of gardeners who appear throughout Our Village.
Group of unnamed characters who are guards in Julian.
Group of unnamed characters who are guards in Rienzi.
Group of three characters who are unnamed journeymen employed by the shoemaker in the titular sketch of Our Village.
Group of unnamed characters who are noble Ladies in Rienzi.
Unnamed group of characters who are small children of the Lieutenant who watch their father skate on the pond in Frost and Thaw.
Group of unnamed characters who are Nobles (i.e., noble gentlemen) in Julian.
Group of unnamed characters who are Nobles (i.e., noble gentlemen) of Rome in Rienzi.
Group of unnamed characters who are officers in Charles I.
Group of characters who are family members of the officer, introduced in the first sketch of Our Village.
Group of unnamed characters who are Prelates in Julian.
Unnamed group of characters who are horseback, coach, and chaise riders whom the narrator describes in Frost and Thaw.
Fictional version of the historical Venetian Senate as represented in Mitford's play Foscari.
Unnamed group of characters who watch the Lieutenant skate on the pond in Frost and Thaw.
The group of characters who are half a dozen ragged urchins, including Jack Rapley, whom the narrator watches sliding on a frozen hill in Frost and Thaw.
Unnamed group of characters who walk on a cold day whom the narrator describes in Frost and Thaw.
Group of unnamed characters who are children of the wheeler. In the titular sketch of Our Village, little Lizzy is said to turn the wheeler's children out of their cart and make them pull her.
Unnamed group of workmen in Our Village whom the renovator hires to work on his house.

person.note: A king in Greek mythology, he wins the princess Alcestis by achieving the feat of yoking a lion and a boar (or bear, in some versions) to a chariot with the help of Apollo. After the wedding, Admetus forgets to make a sacrifice to Artemis and finds his bed full of deadly snakes. He escapes death when his wife Alcestis volunteers to die in his place; Alcestis is then rescued from Hades with the help of Heracles and returns to the land of the living.
Historic and legendary ancient King of Israel, married to Jezebel.

A princess in Greek mythology known for her loyalty to her husband and for returning from the dead. She married King Admetus after he achieves the feat of yoking a lion and a boar (or bear, in some versions) to a chariot. After the wedding, Admetus forgets to make a sacrifice to Artemis and finds his bed full of deadly snakes. He escapes death when Alcestis volunteers to die in his place; Alcestis is then rescued from Hades with the help of Heracles and returns to the land of the living. She is the titular character of a play by Euripides and was the subject of a painting by Angelica Kauffman.
Historical and legendary ancient King of Judah, member of the House of David; the son of Joash and the father of his successor Uzziah.

In Greek mythology, the son of Zeus and Leto; one of the twelve Olympians. He was known as the god of medicine, and later, was associated with the sun god Phoebus; however, his most important association in 18th- and 19th-century literature was as the leader of the Muses, and god of music and poetry. He is conventionally pictured carrying the kithara or lyre, and wearing a laurel wreath, emblems of poetic accomplishment.

Levantine diety associated with Hadad, a storm and fertility god in ancient world religions of Mesopotamia and the Canaanites. The name simply means lord and the god is associated with symbols of bulls, lions, and thunderbolts. In the Old Testament, Baal is represented as the false god of the Canaanites.

Title character in French folktale of the same name. Story was best known in Mitford’s time through a frequently-performed melodrama version, Bluebeard, or Female Curiosity: a Dramatic Romance in Three Acts by George Colman the younger.
Daughter of King Priam and Queen Hecuba of Troy, Cassandra was a prophet in ancient Greek mythology whose prophecies were never believed.

Classical god of sexual desire and erotic love, known as Eros in ancient Greece and Cupid in ancient Rome. In Roman mythology, son of the Roman goddess of love, Venus, and the messenger god, Mercury. Cupid is represented in art and myth as a handsome youth bearing a bow with arrows that he shoots into those whom he wishes to cause to fall in or out of love.

Old Testament figure from the Christian Bible. Apocryphal king of a united kingdom of Israel and Judah. Portrayed as a shepherd and musician, as well as the killer of Goliath, and a favored courtier of King Saul.
Hebrew leader, prophet, and judge, who predicted a woman would kill Sisera, the leader of the Canaanites. Jael fulfilled Deborah’s prophecy.
A character in Arabian aTles (also known as One Thousand and One Nights) who appears in the story variously titled Noureddin Ali of Cairo or Noureddin and his Son.
Greek mythological figure, the goodess of youth and the daughter of Zeus and Hera. Became proverbial for the budding beauty of adolescent women.
Roman god, the son of Jupiter and the mortal Alceme. Known as Heracles in Greek mythology. Proverbial for his strength.

Jael fulfilled Deborah’s prophecy that a woman would kill Sisera, the Canaanite military leader attacking the Israelites. Jael welcomed Sisera into her tent and killed him by pounding a tent stake into his temple.

Queen of the Israelites, married to King Ahab, who influenced him to worship multiple gods, Baal and Asherah, instead of the Hebrew god. She is generally associated with pagan worship and likened to a prostitute in dress and the use of painted cosmetics: hence, the phrase, a painted Jezebel.
Traditionally (and contestedly) the author of the Gospel of John, the fourth book of the New Testament.
Prophet from the Hebrew Bible and Old Testament famous for surviving the experience of being swallowed by a whale.

New Testament figure from the Christian Bible. One of the Jesus's twelve disciples or Apostles, remembered principally as the betrayer of Jesus Christ. His name came to have the colloquial meaning of traitor.
Apocryphal Old Testament figure from the Christian Bible. Famous for seducing then beheading the Assyrian general Holofernes.
Wife of Mr. Punch in manifestations of the Punch and Judy slapstick puppet show tradition from the late eighteenth century onward. Earlier, the character was named Joan.

According to the Gospel of St. John the Evangelist, Jesus Christ raised or resurrected Lazarus from the grave four days after his death. The raising of Lazarus is the subject of a painting by Benjamin Robert Haydon, mentioned in his correspondence with MRM.
Old Master Fuller is a figure found in Collectanea Curiosa, where he appears as Mr. Fuller, in no. XXIII: Mr. Fuller’s Observations of the Shires; his name becomes proverbial.
Apocryphal Old Testament prophet from the Christian Bible; he related his visions to King David.

Greek mythological figure who boasted of her fourteen children, (called the Niobids). As a punishment for her boastfulness, Artemis killed all but one of her children. Became emblematic of tears and extreme sorrow, particularly maternal grief.

New Testament figure from the Christian Bible. One of Jesus's twelve disciples or Apostles, According to the gospels, Peter was a fisherman, had a leadership role amongst the disciples, and denied Jesus three times and later repented. Peter later became the first Bishop of Rome, Pope of the Catholic Church, according to Catholic tradition. Patriarch of Antioch in the Eastern Christian tradition.
Prometheus, the title character in the tragedies attributed to Aeschylus such as Prometheus Bound.

The Punch and Judy slapstick puppet shows of England had their roots in the 16th-century Italian commedia dell’arte tradition. The figure of Punch derives from the Neapolitan stock character of Pulcinella, whose name was anglicized Punchinello and shortened to Punch. 17th- and 18th-century shows in England were performed with marionettes on fixed stages. By the end of the 18th century, shows were performed using glove puppets on mobile puppet booths and found a home on the nineteenth century on the beaches of English seaside resorts and evolved into children’s entertainments in the Victorian era. Mr. Punch is the traditional protagonist of such shows; episodic plots normally involve Punch beating his wife and other characters with his slapstick and end with him defeating even the Devil himself.

Mitford generally refers to the version of the myth from Ovid’s Metamorphoses in which Pygmalion is a sculptor who carves a female statue out of ivory, falls in love with the statue, and Aphrodite brings the statue to life.

persName.note: One of the country boys whom the narrator of Our Village encounters in a number of sketches, notably Frost and Thaw and A Country Cricket Match. In his Mitford papers, Francis Needham identifies two local boys by this name on whom this character may have been based.

person.note: In Judeo-Christian theology, the opponent of God and mankind. The word’s derivation in Hebrew means adversary.
Roman goddess of love and beauty; her counterpart in Greek mythology is Aphrodite.

Vesta is the Roman goddess of hearth and domesticity. The temple to Vesta was kept by priestesses known as Vestal Virgins, who took vows of chastity, a vow enforced under penalty of death. In Rienzi, Claudia’s dedication to Liberty is compared to the life-long commitment of the Vestal Virgins.
character in Deaf and Dumb
Unnamed Abbot Character in Julian.
Character in Alcestis by Euripides.
Alberti is a character in Rienzi; Captain of the Guard. Played by Mr. Thompson as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character of the king of Naples, disguised as Theodore, in Julian.

Possibly a deleted character in Mitford's Charles I. Coles identifies the undated fragment in which Alice appears as having been written in July or August, 1823, although in her letter to Talfourd dated 9 November 1823 , Mitford indicates that she will delete the scene. The character does not appear in the final version of the play.
The character of the unnamed Ambassador in Rienzi.
Wife of Julian, in Julian.
Character in Maria Edgeworth’s Ormond.
Daughter of Lady Annaly in Maria Edgeworth’s Ormond.
Title character in Antigone
Character of an unnamed Archbishop in Julian.
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest who serves Prospero under magical duress.
Character from Virgil’s Aeneid.
Character in The Maid’s Tale.
Character in Old Mortality.
Character in Shakespeare’s Henry V and Henry IV Part I, Henry IV Part II, and the Merry Wives of Windsor.
Niece of Leonato, character in Shakespeare’s Much Ado About Nothing.
Character in Philaster, also called Euphrasia.
Character in Austen’s novel Pride and Prejudice.
Attendant to Claudia in Rienzi.
Bertone, nicknamed Bert, is the character of a servant to Count D'Alba in Julian. Played by Mr. Comer as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.

One of the two characters in Our Village who lodges with the shopkeepers, and teaches children to read and sew. She is mentioned again in A Parting Glance at Our Village, where she is said to marry a respectable tradesman. Surname not given.

Character of a blacksmith introduced in the introductory sketch of Our Village. The narrator mentions that he also holds the office of constable, and has eight children. His fate is recounted in A Parting Glance at Our Village. Surname not given.
Character introduced in the introductory sketch of Our Village . She and her husband have eight children. Proper name not given.

Fictional character loosely based on a 13th-century French trouvére or troubador, either Jean I of Nesle (died 1202) or his son Jean II of Nesle (died 1241), associated with the more than twenty courtly songs attributed to Blondel de Nesle. In the Récits d'un Ménestrel de Reims, Blondel is a mythologized minstrel character who rescues an equally mythologized Richard I from prison through his songs. Blondel's story became popularized in the late eighteenth century and formed the basis for an opera as well as for Eleanor Porden's Coeur de Lion, in which Blondel turns out to be Richard's wife Berengaria in disguise.
A Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Jacobite character in Walter Scott’s Waverley ; He lives at Tully-Veolan, and is the friend of protagonist Edward Waverley’s uncle.
character in The Expedition of Humphrey Clinker by Smollett.
Character in Evelina; Mitford admires Burney’s characterization of him in her a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.
Protagonist of A Village Beau, the Our Village story, where he courts Harriet. He is the half-brother of Lizzy. Francis Needham identifies a local Joel Brent on whom the character was likely based.
Character in Fanny Burney’s Cecilia .

A character in the George Colman the younger play, John Bull the Englishman’s Fireside, a Comedy in five acts. In the play the character is the proprietor of a public house at the sign of the Red Cow.
Character mentioned in the introductory sketch of Our Village . She is noted for living in the only house with sash-windows in the village. Proper name not given.
Character from Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison who is rescued by Sir Charles from other suitors, and later marries him, becoming Lady Grandison.
Lord Cafarello is a character in Rienzi; one of the members of the Colonna faction. Played by Mr. Lee as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest who chafes against his magically-enforced servitude to Prospero.
a Sicilian noble in Julian
daughter of Senator Donato in Mitford’s play Foscari
Camillo is a character in Rienzi; Rienzi's servant. Played by Mr. C. Jones as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Title character in Bickerstaff’s comedy The Hypocrite , an adaptation of Tartuffe by Molière.

Protagonist in A Tale of Two Cities; he is a young, alcoholic London junior barrister upon whose self-reformation and self-sacrifice during the Reign of Terror forms a hinge upon which the plot turns.
Character in The Abbot.
Character in Foscari; mentioned in the Cast List as a follower of Erizzo. played by Mr. Fitzharris.
A character in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
King of England in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Title character of Samuel Richardson’s novel The History of Sir Charles Grandison. Became proverbial for an impossibly perfect ideal man and used by Mitford in this sense.
Title character of Samuel Richardson’s novel Clarissa. Became proverbial for an impossibly perfect ideal woman and used by Mitford in this sense.
daughter of Cola di Rienzi in Rienzi.
A character from Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison, who refuses to marry Sir Charles.
Character of the county clerk who performs the marriage ceremony between Hannah Wilson and William Smith in the Our Village story Hannah. Proper name not given.
Character in Austen’s novel Pride and Prejudice.
Character in Rienzi.
Wife of Stephen Colonna in Rienzi.
Character in Rienzi. Father of Angelo Colonna
Character in The Life and Death of King John.
Cook Mitford hired in Reading for Bertram House on February 13, 1819. Works for about a year, as another Cook is hired on March 14, 1820. May be Anne. Name unknown. Dates unknown.

Cook Mitford hired Reading for Bertram House on March 14, 1820. She is employed for about a week, then resigns or is fired, as another Cook is hired on March 21. Mrs. Hudswell tells her about their old Cook's misconduct, as reported in the Journal on March 14, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.
Cook Mitford hired Readingfor Bertram House, ahead of their move to Three Mile Cross on March 21, 1820. Name unknown. Dates unknown.
Solicitor to the Commons in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Title character in Coriolanus
son of Senator Donato in Foscari
Cromwell’s character in King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.

The character of the curate is introduced in the first sketch of Our Village . He has lodgings with the wheeler's family but lives in another town. In the A Parting Glance at Our Village, he is said to be giving up his lodgings there. Full name not given.

Character in Peacock’s Nightmare Abbey. Identified by Mitford and others as a satirical portrait of Coleridge. Peacock’s footnote indicates that his name is a corruption of Filosky, from the Greek philoskios (φιλοσκιος), a lover, or sectator, of shadows.
a powerful Nobleman in Julian.
Character in Guy Mannering.
Character in Austen’s novel Pride and Prejudice.
The character of the Dauphin is the son of the King of France in Shakespeare’s Henry V.
character in The Heart of Midlothian by Walter Scott , heroine and sister of Effie Deans. She walks from Edinburgh to London to secure a pardon for her sister on a charge of infanticide.
Character in Old Mortality by Walter Scott . Edith Bellenden’s maid.
character in Othello
Character from Virgil’s Aeneid; Aeneas’s wife.
character in Guy Mannering.

note.p: character in Much Ado About Nothing

person.note: character in Mitford’s play Foscari See also historical counterpart: Doge Foscari.
Title character in Don Quixote
character in Foscari
See also historical counterpart: Senator Donato.
Character in The Antiquary
A Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Character in Camilla; Mitford admires Burney’s characterization of him in her a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.
In As You Like It, the character of Duke Senior, the older brother of the usurping Duke Frederick, and father to Rosalind.
Name of idealized female character in Don Quixote (who is mentioned in the text but never appears). Proverbial for an ideal woman.
character in The Antiquary.
Character mentioned in the Our Village, volume 1 sketch Hannah as a poor competitor to John Wilson's abilities as a man-of-all-trades.
Steenie’s grandmother in Walter Scott’s The Antiquary .
Count Erizzo, character in Mitford’s play Foscari
One of the villagers mentioned in the introductory sketch of Our Village . He is a gardener who, having lost his wife, spent several years at an asylum and now resides in the workhouse.
Deceased wife of the Our Village sketch character John Evans. Forename not given.
General of the Parliamentary Army in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Character in Shakespeare’s Henry IV, part one, Henry IV, part two, and Merry Wives of Windsor
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest who is shipwrecked on Prospero's Island, and falls in love with Miranda. No surname given.
Title character of Mitford’s tragedy Fiesco.
Character in Peacock’s Nightmare Abbey. Identified by Mitford and others as a satirical portrait of Byron. Much of his misanthropical conversation is taken from the fourth canto of Childe Harold.
character in Foscari
See also historical counterpart: son of Doge Foscari.

Character in the Our Village sketch Modern Antiques. She and her sister Theodosia are said to have been intimates of Samuel Richardson and the Bluestockings. Frances is the sister who is rumored to have a longtime beau. Although she uses the honorific Mrs., she is unmarried. Surname not given.
Character in Rienzi, a partisan of Ursini, also a nobleman. Played by Mr. Bland as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.
Character who becomes Robinson Crusoe's friend and companion in Daniel Defoe's The Adventures of Robinson Crusoe.

persName.note: Character mentioned in the Our Village sketch Frost and Thaw whom the narrator observes. Proper name not given.

person.note: Secondary character in Douglas.
Son of King Charles I, a boy of seven years old in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Roundhead character in The Roundhead's Daughter; father of the title character.
Title character in The Roundhead's Daughter.

Character in The Clerk's Tale from Canterbury Tales, also called Griselda or Patient Grizzle who became proverbial for a patient, obedient, long-suffering wife. Mitford may have been familiar with the 1782 Martins edition of the Poetical Works of Geoffrey Chaucer, in which this tale appears in volume 3.
Character in the pantomime Tom Thumb. John Liston played Lord Grizzle in a Haymarket production in 1810.
Character in Marriage. Mitford’s favorite character from the novel; she admires the character’s portrayal and teasingly contemplates naming Sir William’s kitten after her.
Titular character in Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels.
Colonel of the Guard in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
character in Hamlet
Governor of the Isle of Wight in Mitford’s play, Charles I.

One of the two characters introduced in Our Village who lodges with the shopkeepers, and teaches children to read and sew. She appears in several sketches, including Nutting and A Village Beau, where she is courted by Joel Brent Surname not given.
A Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
character in Helen
character in Bonduca
Character in Walter Scott’s novel The Abbot.
A Gentleman attending on the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
character in The Winter’s Tale
Character in Camilla; Mitford admires Burney’s characterization of him in her a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.
Character in Othello.
character in Cymbeline
A Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Character from Dante’s Inferno.
Sister of Claudio, character in Shakespeare’s Measure for Measure .
A character from the play Wild Oats.
Character in Marriage; Mitford admires Ferrier’s characterization of her.
character in Foscari

Character described in the Our Villagesketch, The Hard Summer . He is one of the country boys who populate the village. Francis Needhamspeculates that the family name may have been Cusden. Source: NeedhamPapers, Reading Central Library.
Character in Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison. She is the ward of Sir Charles Grandison.
Melfi’s son in Julian
Most powerful official of the law in England. Character in Shakespeare’s Henry IV Part II.
character in Henry VIII
King Corny was the king of Ireland in Maria Edgeworth’s Ormond (1817)
King Philip is the King of France in Shakespeare’s King John
Married to Lord Fairfax in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
A character in Lady Morgan’s novel The O’Donnel’s.
Character in Walter Scott’s novel Kenilworth. Nephew of innkeeper Giles Gosling.
Senator Donato’s niece in Foscari, as mentioned in Cast List
a Sicilian noble in Julian
Character in Rule a Wife and Have a Wife by Beaumont and Fletcher
character in The Winter’s Tale
Character mentioned in the introductory sketch of Our Village . He also appears skating on a frozen pond in Frost and Thaw, to the delight of many spectators. Proper name not given.
Character in Austen’s novel Pride and Prejudice.

The three-year-old girl who often accompanies the narrator of Our Village on her walks. In the story A Village Beau, she is identified as the half-sister of Joel Brent, who is one of the cricketers and the protagonist of A Village Beau. In the Introduction to the third volume of Our Village, the narrator give an account of what happens to several villagers, Lizzy among them. In his Mitford papers, Francis Needham identifies an Eliza Brent as the probable original for the character.
Father of the character of LizzyLizzy, the three-year old girl who accompanies the narrator of Our Village on many of her walks. He is said to be a carpenter. Forename not given.
Mother of the character of Lizzy, the three-year old girl who accompanies the narrator of Our Village on many of her walks. Forename not given.

Title character of the Our Village story. Lucy is a servant in the narrator's household who leaves to get married. The character appears in several stories, notably Hannah and A Visit to Lucy. According to Needham's Mitford papers, the character is based on the servant in the Mitford household, Lucy Sweetser Hill. Surname not given.
Title character in Macbeth.
Character in Macbeth
Character in Marriage; Mitford admires Ferrier’s characterization of her.

note.p: Character in Deaf as a Post

person.note: Character from Arabian Tales.
Character in Camilla; Mitford says of this character that the very name is as stiff as poker, in a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.
Character in Don Quixote. Servant at the inn who makes an appointment with Don Quixote’s carrier for a tryst, but mistakes Don Quixote for the carrier, with comic results.
A Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Heroine of Marriage. Mitford does not admire Ferrier’s depiction of her heroine, considering her to be too perfect, a female Sir Charles Grandison.
Fictional pet dog in Tom Cordery.

Character introduced in the first sketch of Our Village . He is said to be particularly short, and to live in a pretty white cottage. His son, John Strong, is one of the cricketers who appears in A Country Cricket Match. Forename not given.

Wife of the mason in Our Village. She is said to be tall, contrasting his shortness, and to have gardening skills that make the narrator jealous. She is the mother of John Strong, one of the cricketers from A Country Cricket Match. Forename not given.
Master Peter is the puppetmaster in Don Quixote; his puppets are destroyed in the course of the novel.
Greyhound dog who is featured as the narrator's companion in many Our Villagesketches.
Character in Maria Edgeworth’s Ormond (1817)
character in Guy Mannering.
Uncle to Alfonso and Regent of the Kingdom of Naples in Julian
Character in Shakespeare's The Tempest. She is the daughter of Prospero and is in love with Ferdinand.
A character in Lady Morgan’s novel Florence Macarthy.
One of the servant characters in Modern Antiques from Our Village. Proper name not given.

Unnamed character in the Our Village sketch, Modern Antiques, who is rumored to be a longtime suitor to Mrs. Frances. In his Mitford Papers, Needham identifies the character as based on Francis Annesley, LL.D.. Proper name not given.
Character in Modern Antiques in Our Village. He is the younger brother of elderly beau from that story. Proper name not given.

death.placeName: Broomhill and Sharrow Vale, Sheffield, Yorkshire, England

person.note: Editor of the Sheffield Iris and friend of Barbara Hofland. Political reformer affiliated with the Moravian Bretheren, he supported reformist causes such as the abolition of slavery and child labor, and was imprisoned in the 1790s for sedition. He is also a hymn-writer, including Angels from the Realms of Glory and Prayer is the Soul's Sincere Desire.
Royalist character in The Roundhead's Daughter.
Protagonist in John Gibson Lockhart’s 1819 novel, Peter’s Letters to his Kinfolk.

Title character of the Our Village sketch, Mrs. Mosse. Nicknamed Mossy. She is a longtime servant in the household of the narrator and, according to Francis Needham, based on the Mitfords' own servant, Mrs. Cropp. Source: NeedhamPapers, Reading Central Library.
A character in Lady Morgan’s novel The O’Donnel’s.
Character in Maria Edgeworth’s Ormond (1812)
Portia’s maid, character in Shakespeare’s Merchant of Venice. Nerissa disguises herself as a male law clerk when Portia disguises herself as a lawyer.

Character in Our Village, volume 5, Early Recollections: A Widow Gentlewoman. According to Needham, she is based on a real acquaintance from Mitford's early years named Mrs. Nicholson, who was the widow of Jeremiah Nicholson, D.D., the vicar of . Source: NeedhamPapers, Reading Central Library. Forename not given.
Character in Marriage; Mitford admires Ferrier’s characterization of her.
Pseudonym for John Wilson in Blackwood’s Magazine.
Character in Rienzi. Known by his title; no proper name given.
Character in Shakespeare’s Henry V and Merry Wives of Windsor.
Hero of Homer's The Odyssey, whose twenty-year journey to return home from the Trojan War is chronicled.
Character in Maria Edgeworth’s Ormond (1817)
Character introduced in Our Village. He lives with his family in a small detached cottage. Proper name not given.
Character introduced in Our Village as admiring Lizzy. Proper name not given.
character in The Antiquary.
Character of an Irish hedge schoolmaster in Lady Morgan's novel Florence Macarthy (I.284).
One of the Ladies in Foscari
Orestes, title character in the play Choephoræ or the Libation Bearers, attributed to Aeschylus.
Orestes, title character in the play Orestes attributed to Euripides.
Orlando de Boys who falls in love with Rosalind in Shakespeare’s As You Like It.
Protagonist of Maria Edgeworth’s Ormond (1812).

The narrator and purported author of a cycle of epic poems published by James Macpherson beginning in 1760. Macpherson claimed to have translated the work of Ossian from ancient and folkloric sources in Gaelic but critical consensus is that Macpherson created the poems himself based on word-of-mouth folk material he collected. The character of Ossian is based on Oisín, son of Finn or Fionn mac Cumhaill, later anglicised to Finn McCool, a legendary bard from the Irish folk tradition. The character appears in Fragments of Ancient Poetry collected in the Highlands of Scotland, and translated from the Galic or Erse language , and Temora, an ancient epic poem .
character in Othello

The narrator of all the Our Village stories. Though unnamed throughout the series, her activities and interests, the people she mentions and the language she uses all closely mirror those of Mitford. Proper name not given.

The character of the father of the narrator of the Our Village stories. In some sketches, such as Hannah, he appears as a speaking character, while in others he is merely mentioned. His character hews closely to that of George Mitford. Proper name not given.

The character of the mother of the narrator of the Our Village stories. In some sketches, she appears as a speaking character, while in others she is mentioned or alluded to. Her character resembles that of Mary Russell, Mitford's mother. Proper name not given.
Paolo is the character of Julian's servant in Julian. Surname not given. Played by Mr. Ley as performed at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, February 1823.
Paolo, the character in Rienzi.

In The Odyssey, Penelope is the spouse of Odysseus who awaited his return and fended off suitors by weaving and secretly unweaving a tapestry, whose completion signified her readiness to choose a new husband.
character in Wheel of Fortune.

Character in Metamorphoses, book two. Phaeton attempts to drive his father the Sun’s chariot and winged horses and must be killed by Jupiter when he loses control of the vehicle and endangers the earth.

Character introduced in Our Village as the daughter of the Rose Inn landlord. She is wooed by the recruiting serjeant, but in A Village Beau is said to have married a patten-maker. Surnames not given.
Protagonist of Tobias Smollett’s The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle, In Which are Included Memoirs of a Lady of Quality (1751)
Character of a jester who serves the King in Gaston de Blondeville.
Character of Count Pisani in Foscari.
character in Guy Mannering.
Chief counselor of the king; character in Shakespeare’s Hamlet.
The character of an Officer in the Parliamentary Army in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Addison. See also the character's historical counterpart: Thomas Pride.

person.persName: Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn
person.note: 4th son of King George III, his daughter became Queen Victoria, following the 1817 death of Princess Charlotte, the royal family's only other legitimate grandchild. Served as a British army officer in Quebec and Halifax in the 1790s and played an influential role in the UK's changing relations with Upper and Lower Canada and with the United States. From 1799, he served as Commander-in-Chief of British forces in North America. Also served with the rank of Field Marshal in the French Revolutionary and Coalition (Napoleonic) Wars. He died of pneumonia and Mitford dons mourning dress for him.

The second daughter of Charles I and Queen Henrietta Maria. She was imprisoned during the English Civil Wars from age six to her death from pneumonia in 1650 at age fourteen. She is portrayed as a girl aged twelve, in Mitford's play, Charles I.
Main character from Shakespeare's The Tempest who, upon being shipwrecked on an island with his daughter, Miranda, has learned sorcery and magic.
Queen of England in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Comic role in Henry Fielding’s play Tom Thumb, adapted in Mitford’s day by Kane O’Hara as a comic opera, with Sarah Tyrer famously playing this role.
character in Hamlet
Character in Glenfergus by Mudie.
character in Ivanhoe.
Character mentioned in Our Village who is courting Phoebe. In A Parting Glance at Our Village, he is said to have already been married. Proper name not given.
Character of an old Huntsman in Julian

A particularly patriotic character introduced in Our Village. He is based on a neighbor of Mitford's, who held an illumination for the acquittal of Queen Caroline, a local event she describes rather disapprovingly in a letter to William Elford on November 21, 1820. The retired publican's fate is described further in A Parting Glance at Our Village, where he is referred to as blind Robert. Full name not given.
The wife of the character of the retired publican from the introductory sketch of Our Village . Proper name not given.
Title character from Shakespeare's The Life and Death of Richard III, loosely based on the historical King Richard III. One of William Macready's most prominent roles.
Title character from Edward Bulwer-Lytton Richelieu, loosely based on the historical Cardinal Richelieu; role created by and for William Macready.
character in Rienzi.
Mischievous fairy or sprite from folklore. In Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream, he causes romantic havoc for the other characters, both human and fairy.
Titular character of Daniel Defoe's famous novel about a man shipwrecked near Trinidad.
character in Pizarro
Attendant to Claudia in Rienzi
Character introduced in Our Village, the introductory sketch of the Our Village series. Proper name not given.
This character is introduced in Our Village. He is the brother of Phoebe. Proper name not given.
This character is introduced in Our Village. She has a son, and a daughter named Phoebe. Proper name not given.
Character in Ivanhoe
A Commissioner appointed by Parliament to treat with the King in Mitford's play, Charles I.
Squire character, a former farmer enlisted by Don Quixote in his service, from Don Quixote.
Title character from Byron's tragedy Sardanapalus, about a doomed Assyrian tyrant. Role William Macready originated the role in 1834, after Byron's death.
Lord Savelli is a character in Rienzi; one of the members of the Colonna faction. Played by Mr. Aitken as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, October 9, 1828.

The character of a Commissioner appointed by Parliament to treat with the King in Mitford's play, Charles I. Original role created by Mr. Mildenhall. See also the character's historical counterpart: William Say.
Character in Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night.
A character in Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison.
A character Samuel Richardson's The History of Sir Charles Grandison.
Character from George Farquhar's play The Recruiting Officer. Forename not given.
The character of the servant belonging to Cromwell in Mitford's play, Charles I. No proper name given. Original role created by Mr. Kerridge.
Character of Sforza in Foscari. See also the character's historical counterpart: General Sforza.
A character whom the narrator encounters in the Our Village story Frost and Thaw Proper name not given..
Character described in Our Village as a sober, industrious man. Proper name not given.

Character described in Our Village. She goes from the age of fourteen to sixteen from the first story to the final one in the first series, A Parting Glance at Our Village. She is said to be the narrator's opposite neighbour, suggesting a proximity of residence to the family. Proper name not given.
Character introduced in Our Village. Proper name not given.
Character mentioned in Our Village. Proper name not given.
Character mentioned in Our Village. Proper name not given.
Character in the Our Village, volume 1 story Hannah. He is the father of the suitor, William. Forename not given.
Character of the suitor of Hannah in the Our Village story of that name.
Character in Evelina; Mitford admires Burney’s characterization of him in her a letter to Elford from 30 May 1819.
Character in Tobias Smollett’s The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle (1751)

Son of the Our Village character the mason and the mason's wife. He appears as a cricket player in A Country Cricket Match. A George Strong, bricklayer and beer retailer, as well as an Elizabeth Strong, baker, are identified by Francis Needham in his Mitford papers.
Attendant to Claudia in Rienzi

One of the two sister characters in the Our Village story Modern Antiques. Theodosia is her forename, and Mrs. is an honorific, since the character is unmarried. She and her sister, Frances are said to have been intimates of Samuel Richardson and the Bluestockings. Surname not given.
A Judge appointed by Parliament to try the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.

Pseudonym used by Mr. Johnson. Author of A Letter to the Independent Electors of Westminster (1809), Timothy Trueman’s Admonitions to the Clergy (1816), and The Curse of Gehazi (1819). Not the same as the author of the American publications The Burlington Almanac and The New Jersey Almanac.

Title character of the doctor in the Our Village, volume two sketch. Francis Needham, in his Mitford Papers, identifies a local man by this name who may have been the basis for this character. In the Lady's Magazine version of the story, the title is Doctor Casden. Forename not given.
Character from Dante’s Inferno. Guilty of treason.
character in Otto of Wittelsbach
Leader of the Ursini family in Mitford’s Rienzi.
a Sicilian noble in Julian
A Commissioner appointed by Parliament to treat with the King in Mitford’s play, Charles I.
Character in Walter Scott’s novel Kenilworth. Squire to the Earl of Leicester.

Character of the vicar from Our Village, volume 1, who, in the sketch A Parting Glance at Our Village, is said to be moving into the newly-renovated house of the wealthy, whimsical man. Proper name not given.
Character in Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night.
Mr. Sidney's pet terrier in An Old Bachelor.
character in Coriolanus

Character introduced in Our Village as an wealthy man who continually refurbishes the house he owns in the village. He re-appears in A Parting Glance at Our Village to finish the work, and let the house to the incoming vicar. Proper name not given.
Squire Western’s daughter, model of virtue, beauty, and all good qualities. Character in The History of Tom Jones, A Foundling by Henry Fielding (1749)
Character introduced in Our Village as a very civil and courteous man. The curate lodges at his family's house, distinctive for its green door and knocker. Proper name not given.
Character introduced in Our Village. With her husband, she lodges the curate at her home. Proper name not given.

The White Spirit is a supernatural guardian spirit character in
Walter Scott’s The Monastery .
One of the cricket players featured in A Country Cricket Match. In his Mitford Papers, Francis Needham identifies a local boy bearing this name, as well as others with the Willis family name.
A character in the Our Village sketch Hannah. She is the mother of Hannah and the widow of John Wilson. Forename not given.
Title character of the Our Village story Hannah. She is wooed by the secretly wealthy William Smith.
Character in the Our Village story Hannah. He is the deceased father of the title character who was renowned for his skill in all trades.
Younger sister of the character Hannah, the title character of the Our Village story.
Title character from Knowles's play William Tell, loosely based on the pseudohistorical Swiss revolutionary; role created by and for William Macready.
character in Henry VIII
Count Zeno in Foscari

org.note: In Greek mythology, the fifty daughters of Danaus. They are to condemned to spend eternity carrying water in leaky vessel or sieve, and so become proverbial for an impossible task that cannot be completed.

In Greek (and later Roman) mythology, the nine goddesses who live on Mount Helicon and inspire mortals to create. Although in some traditions there were only three Muses, by the Hellenistic period, nine was the accepted number, and they were believed to be led by Apollo. By the neoclassical period, emblem books, sculpture, and painting had standardized the depictions of the goddesses: Calliope (epic poetry) carries a writing tablet and stylus or a lyre; Clio (history) carries a scroll or books; Euterpe (lyric poetry and song) carries a flute (the aulos); Erato (erotic/love poetry) carries a lyre or cithera or a crown of roses; Melpomene (tragedy) is seen with a tragic mask; Polyhymnia (sacred poetry) is depicted veiled or with a pensive expression; Terpsichore (choral song and dance) is depicted dancing or with a lyre; Thalia (comedy) is seen with a comic mask or shepherd's crook; and Urania (astronomy) carries compasses and a celestial globe.
The highest order of angel according to the Christian religion.

place.note: Abingdon (now called Abingdon on Thames or Abingdon-on-Thames,) is a market town in Oxfordshire. In Mitford’s time, it was the county town of the county of Berkshire. It was reassigned to Oxfordshire in 1974. In the nineteenth century, the Assize Courts alternated between Reading and Abingdon, according to Coles.
Body of water that separates Italy from the Balkans.

Agincourt is a commune in the Meurthe-et-Moselle department in northeastern France. In English history, best-known as the location of the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, where Henry V consolidated his conquest of France. This event is memorialized in Shakespeare’s play Henry V .
Village that Mitford mentions visiting with her father and the dogs in the Journal, 10 November 1820. They continued on that day to the village of Tadley.

Birthplace of Mary Russell Mitford, who lived at 27 Broad Street until about the age of four; the family moved to Reading in 1791. During Mitford’s time and earlier, inhabitants made a distinction between Old Alresford and New Alresford. In the parish records for their marriage, George Mitford and Mary Russell indicated their current place of residence as Old Alresford and their future residence as New Alresford.
For generalized references to the Americas.

The capital and largest city init the Netherlands. A key center for finance and trade in Europe from the 17th century, including the book trade. Although Holland became part of the French empire during the Napoleonic era, the Kingdom of the Netherlands was established in 1815, creating new trading opportunities for the capital city.

The capital city of Antwerp Province in the Flemish Region, known colloquially as Flanders, in Belgium. Before the Reformation, Antwerp rose to become a powerful trading city under the rule of the Spanish. With the Union of Utrecht in 1579, the city became part of the United Provinces of the Netherlands, and the port was subsequently closed by treaty agreement, leading to the decline in the city's trading status. During Mitford's lifetime, Antwerp was controlled by Napoleonic France, and after the Battle of Waterloo, it became part of the Kingdom of the United Netherlands until 1832, when it was joined to Belgium following a siege by French forces.
In Mitford's time, the Ashmolean collection was housed in the 1683 Old Ashmolean, a purpose-built museum on Broad Street that now houses Oxford's History of Science Museum.
Assize Court building in central Reading. The current Reading Crown Court Building was not built until 1861, after Mitford's death.
Ancient world city-state and currently the capital of Greece. During Mitford's time, a stop on the Grand Tour, frequently referenced in literature as the center of Western civilization and learning.
The capital city of Greece. The city was named after Athena, the Greek goddess of wisdom.

The ocean that extends between, on the Eastern side, Europe and Africa, and, on the West, the New World (the Americas). Historically known as the Sea of Atlas, after the mythological character who holds up the world.
During Mitford’s life, the Essexfamily seat of Richard Griffin, second Baron Braybrooke.

Country in central Europe, now the Republic of Austria, made up of nine federated states, whose capital is Vienna. From the 16th century, a center of the Habsburg monarchy and an archduchy and center of the Holy Roman Empire. In the early 19th century, Austria established itself as an empire and a leading power in the German Confederation.

Runs between Ludgate Hill and Amen Court in the City of London. Home to the Stationer's Hall, the guild hall of the Worshipful Company of Stationers and Newspaper Makers since 1670. In Mitford's time, the location of the Whittaker family's publishing house.

place.placeName: The Banqueting House, Whitehall, London, England
place.note: Designed by Inigo Jones, the Banqueting House in London is the only surviving remnant of Whitehall Palace, as it was in Mitford’s lifetime. It was also the scene of the Regicide in 1649.
Area within the London City Corporation.

J. B. Monck lived at 10 Barton Street in the 1820s. Mitford mentions this as his London address in an 1821 letter to Elford. Barton Street intersects Great College Street, near Westminster School and the College Garden.
Town in Hampshire, in south central England, near the source of the River Loddon.

A city in the county of Somerset in south west England, located in the valley of the River Avon, near Bristol. A resort and spa town since Roman times, known for its mineral hot springs. Now a UNESCO world heritage site.

place.placeName: The Bear Inn, Reading, Berkshire, England
place.note: Located at 22 Bridge Street in Reading. Building no longer standing.

Beaurepaire House was the seat and estate of the Brocas family, located in Bramley, and including substantial lands. The house was demolished and replaced with a gothic-style manor around 1738, and was home to Bernard Brocas until his death, though it remained in the family and sometimes visited Harriot Brocas. The estate remained in the family until it was sold in 1870.
The county town of Bedfordshire, in the east of England. It was founded at a ford on the River Great Ouse.
The county of Berkshire, England, abbreviated Berks.
In London, location of nearest postal receiving office to Barbara Hofland’s address on Newman Street, two blocks away.

Mansion built by George Mitford for his family residence, begun in April 1802 and completed in June 1804, after tearing down the previous house on the property, Grazeley Court Farm, a farmhouse about three miles outside of Reading, in the hamlet of Grazeley. George Mitford named his new house after a knight from the reign of William the Conqueror, Sir Robert de Bertram, who had married Sibella Mitford, daughter of Sir John de Mitford (source: Vera Watson). This estate signified George Mitford’s status as a land-owning country gentleman. Prior to this time, the Mitford family lived in Alresford and then in Reading. The family removed from Bertram House in April 1820, after financial reverses forced the family to sell the property.

Hamlet near Plymouth, and residence of Sir William Elford, who lived there until the failure of his finances in 1825 forced him eventually to sell his family’s estate. He sold his property in Bickham in 1831 and moved to The Priory, in Totnes, Devon the house of his daughter (Elizabeth) and son-in-law.
During Mitford’s life, the Berkshire estate of Richard Griffin, second Baron Braybrooke. Billingbear House was destroyed by fire in 1924 and no longer stands.

A city in the West Midlands, formerly part of the historic county of Warwickshire. In Mitford’s time, the city was at the center of the Industrial Revolution, with developments in the skilled trades, steam power, railways and canals, and banking beginning in the eighteenth century. During the nineteenth century, the city became the second-largest popular center, after London, and became a center for political radicalism and reform.
A manor house in Berkshire, named for the priory that once stood on the site. It is now a grade I listed manor house.
A fashionable shopping street in the West End of London.

One of the oldest cities in America; an important New England seaport, trading center, and center of the publishing trade in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. A key site of events of the War of American Independence.
Village in Hampshire, located ten miles south of Reading, near Silchester.
A parish in the county of Hampshire, near Farley Hill and Swallowfield.
Largest country in South America.
An Italian river that flows from the Trentino region in northern Italy into the Adriatic Sea just south of Venice.
In the nineteenth century, a village near Hownslow, west of London at the confluence of the Thames and the River Brent. It was the historic county town of Middlesex. Now part of Greater London.

Northern Italian city ruled by the Venetian Republic in the mid-fifteenth century, and again during the mid-sixteenth century after a brief period of French rule. Brescia remained a Venetian possession until the Republic of Venice fell to Napoleon's 1797 Italian campaign. From 1815, Brescia became part of the Kingdom of Lombardy-Venetia controlled by Austria and several revolutionary movements against Austrian rule occurred in the 19th century. After being conquered by Italy, Brescia becomes part of the unified Kingdom Italy in 1859.
A resort town on the south coast of Great Britain, popularized by George IV while Prince Regent. Until 1810, the town’s official name was Brighthelmstone.

City in county of the same name in south west England. Historically, an important seaport from which ships left on voyages of discovery and trade to the New World, and a center of fishing and shipbuilding. Bristol and Liverpool ports formed part of the Atlantic trade in West Africans taken for slavery to the Americas. Also a center of abolitionism, nonconformist religious activity, and political reform. Northern terminus of the Great Western Railway that linked southwest England to London-Paddington.
County in southeast England; one of the home counties nearest to London. County town is Aylesbury. Abbreviated Bucks.

Began in the twelfth century as a central market district for Birmingham. From the 1830s to the 1860s, also a popular location for public preaching and political protests. Location of the 1839 Chartist demonstration for voting reform in England, known as the Bull Ring Riots.
Hamlet near Reading named after a bridge crossing the River Kennett. The existing bridge was constructed in 1812 and is a Grade II listed building.
English country house that has been the seat of the Earls of Essex since Elizabethan times. Its name is featured in stories and poems about Henry Cecil and his second wife, Sarah Hoggins.

An area that was set aside for the poor upon the enclosure of Mortimer Common in 1802. The spot features prominently in Tom Cordery as a place where the protagonist leads his clients on unsuccessful hunting trips.
City on the river Cam, north of London, in Cambridgeshire. Location of Cambridge University.
Village near Newport on the Isle of Wight. Charles I was imprisoned at Carisbrooke Castle in this village before his trial.

District on the outskirts of London, between Camden Town and Hampstead: the site of the duel between John Scott and Jonathan Christie on 16 February 1821, which resulted in Scott’s death. In the eighteenth and early nineteenth century, a frequent location for duels, as it was near London and yet thinly populated and secluded.

Before the early 20th century, Charing Cross referred to a district (and postal address) in the Whitehall region of central London between Great Scotland Yard and Trafalgar Square in the former hamlet of Charing. Charing Cross also refers to the name of the junction of Strand, Whitehall, and Cockspur streets. The district is named for the Eleanor cross that once stood at the junction, which was erected in the 1290s in honor of Eleanor of Castile and was removed by the Parliamentarians during the English Civil War; a statue of Charles I has stood in its place since 1675.
County in the north west of England. Its county town is Chester.

spacious and populous land in East Asia with an ancient history, of interest to the English in the nineteenth century for trade in tea, porcelain, and silk, for which the East India Company supplied opium against Chinese law.
Market town in Wiltshire, east of Bath. Founded on the River Avon and served by the Great Western Railway after 1841.
City in south west Ohio, settled in 1788 at the confluence of the Licking and Ohio Rivers.

An estate just south west of Reading. The Moncks owned Coley Park from 1810 and Mitford occasionally posted franked letters from there when J. B Monck was a Member of Parliament. Also referred to as Coley, although this name also refers to a nearby district of Reading proper.
Mr. Dearesley's copse near Bertram House. Mitford went primrosing there in March 1819. Source: Journal.
House belonging to Richard Body in Three Mile Cross where Mary Russell Mitford moved with her parents in 1820 after leaving Bertram House. Mitford lived there until 1851.

place.placeName: Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, London, England
place.note: A West End theater located in Covent Garden in the London borough of Westminster. One of the royal patent theaters. The first theater on this site was opened in 1732 by John Rich, renovated by architect Henry Holland in 1792, and destroyed by fire on 20 Sept. 1808. The second theater, designed by Robert Smirke, opened on 18 Sept. 1809 and was managed by John Phillip Kemble. Because of rent increases by the Duke of Bedford, the landowner, J.P. Kemble increased ticket prices. This led to the old price (or O.P.) riots and the eventual lowering of ticket prices, although the proprietors proved they would lose money at those prices. The second theater was destroyed by fire on 5 March 1856. The third theater, designed by Edward Middleton Barry, opened in 1858 and remains at the center of today’s theater complex. The theater became the Royal Opera House in 1892 and the building was renovated and expanded in the 1980s and 1990s.
City in the West Midlands in England, formerly associated with Warwickshire.
Village in northern France. Location of the Battle of Crécy in 1436, during which Edward III of England and his allied troops achieved a significant victory over France in the Hundred Years’ War.
County in the south west of England bordering the English Channel and the Bristol Channel. Now called Devon.
The county of Devonshire, now known as Devon, in the south west of England.

Ruined medieval castle, of which only the 14th-century gatehouse remains standing. In 1398, Thomas Chaucer, the brother of the poet Chaucer, purchased the castle for his daughter. In 1646, the Castle was captured by Royalist forces and endured an eighteen-month siege by Parliamentarian forces, after which time the main portion of the Castle was demolished. The gatehouse and ruins are now a scheduled ancient monument, number 233041.
A county in southwest England on the English Channel coast. Known as Dorset today, it was traditionally known as Dorsetshire.

place.placeName: Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London, England
place.note: A West End theater located in Covent Garden in the London borough of Westminster. One of the royal patent theatres. Between 1674 and 1791, a building designed by Christopher Wren and commissioned by manager Thomas Killgrew. The Wren building was torn down by R. B. Sheridan and rebuilt. It reopened in 1791 and was destroyed by fire in 1809. The theater reopened in 1812 and still stands today.
The capital and largest city of Ireland, located in the province of Leinster at the mouth of the River Liffey.
The capital and second-largest city in Scotland, located on the Firth of Forth. Site of the University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh Castle, and Holyrood Palace.

A London building in Piccadilly, designed in the Egyptian style, Egyptian Hall was built in 1812 to house William Bullock’s collection of artifacts from Captain Cook’s Pacific voyages. After Bullock auctioned off his South Seas collection, the building was frequently used after 1819 to exhibit panoramas and enormous paintings, such as Benjamin Robert Haydon’s Christ’s Entry into Jerusalem, and The Raising of Lazarus. The building was demolished in 1905.

Street in the Temple area of London. Mitford addressed letters to Talfourd at 2 Elm Court, Temple in the 1820s. Elm Court is located off Middle Temple Lane, just north of Inner Temple, the traditional location of barristers’ chambers in London.
Part of the Atlantic Ocean, it is a body of water that joins the North Sea to the Atlantic and separates southern England from northern France.
Country in the British Isles. Borders Scotland and Wales. London is the capital city, and is situated on the River Thames.

Elizabethan-era country house, currently a Grade II listed building open to the public, which has been used several times as a filming location. During Mitford's lifetime, the estate was owned by of the Benyon family, including Richard Benyon the younger (died 1796) and Richard Benyon De Beauvoir, to whom Mitford dedicated her poem Englefield House in 1822.
County in England, north east of London. County town is Chelmsford.
The European continent, extending in the thinking of Mitford's time roughly south to the Middle East and east to St. Petersburg, and bounded on the west by the Atlantic.

Known colloquially as Change Alley, this narrow street in London was the location of several well-known coffeehouses in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries where stocks and commodities were traded, thus making Exchange Alley a center of commerce that was a precursor of the London Stock Exchange.
Exeter is a cathedral city in the southwest of England, in the county of Devon.
Village in Berkshire, in the parish of Swallowfield. The Dickinsons lived there.
Fields at Burghfield Bridge. George Mitford goes there to get his daughter Field Tulips in April 1819.
Fields belonging to the Bertram House estate. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819. Some of the fields are used for haying.
Fields belonging to the ichard Body. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819.
Fields belonging to Mr. Davies.
Field belonging to the Mr. Dearsley, once part of the Bertram House estate, sold by George Mitford. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819.
Field belonging to Mr. Pithers. One location where Mitford goes violetting in March 1819, although she did not find any that year.
Frequent destination for Mitford walks and drives, accompanied by Lucy & their dogs. Frequent site for collecting flower, including violets, pansies, cowslips, and wood sorrel.
Fields near the cottage at Three Mile Cross.

Region of woodland and heathland, now owned as National Trust land in a parcel that includes Simon's Wood. In Mitford's time, owned by the Walter family. Its fictional counterpart may be the Ridges mentioned in Cousin Mary.

Forested, hilly region in Europe covering parts of the Ardennes mountain range and the Moselle and Meuse River basins. Primarily in Wallonia, Belgium and Oesling, Luxembourg; also encompassing the Ardennes department and Alsace-Champagne-Ardenne-Lorraine region of France.
Castle in the village of Fotheringhay where Mary, Queen of Scots was imprisoned, tried, and executed in 1587. Also the birthplace of King Richard III. Alternate spelling Fotheringay.
Country in western Europe. Paris is the capital and largest city.

A piece of ground near Mortimer Common mentioned in Tom Cordery as a spot where two murderers were hanged. Mitford recalls going to this place in a letter of January 13, 1842 to Elizabeth Barrett Browning.
Garden at Bertram House estate.
A country in central-western Europe. Berlin is the capital and largest city.

Largest city in Scotland, on the River Clyde. Historically part of the county of Lanarkshire. Since the eighteenth century, an important center of trade and emigration with the Americas. Also a key center of the Industrial Revolution, particularly in shipbuilding and related industries.
Village in Shinfield parish in Berkshire, the site of the the Mitford’s residence from 1802 to 1820, Bertram House.

Southeastern European country at the southernmost tip of the Balkan peninsula. In Mitford's time, Greece was a part of the Ottoman Empire and became a modern nation state in 1830, following a war for independence fought in the 1820s. In 1826, the UK, France and the Russian empire join to assist the war effort. Mitford would also have known that Byron died in 1824 in Ottoman Greece, after leading a war campaign followed by two sieges of Missolonghi.
One of the houses Mitfords view but do not choose in planning their relocation from Bertram Housein 1820.

place.placeName: Guildhall, City of London, London, England
place.note: A building (and its main room, a medieval-era great hall) used as a town hall and administrative center for the Corporation of the City of London. It is situated off Gresham and Basinghall streets, in the wards of Bassishaw and Cheap. Site of the Sheriff’s Court in London over which John Bradshaw presided as judge from 1640 to 1659. Guildhall is now a Grade I listed building.
County on the southern coast of England, known historically as the County of Southampton. The county town is Winchester. Abbreviated Hants.
Village nearLondon, north west of Charing Cross, now enclosed by it. Its population was rapidly growing through the nineteenth century, and Hampstead Heath is now a public park.

place.placeName: Hampstead Theatre, Swiss Cottage, Camden, London, England
place.note: Theater in the Swiss Cottage area near Hampstead, in the London Borough of Camden; commissions and produces new theater writing and supports the work of new playwrights. The original theater production company, The Hampstead Theatre Club, was founded in 1959. In 2003 the theater company moved to a new purpose-built location in Swiss Cottage.

Built in the early sixteenth century by Cardinal Wolsey, then, after Wolsey’s fall, the residence of Henry VIII, Hampton Court Palace has been the residence of royals including George II, who was the last monarch to occupy it as an official residence. Charles I spent part of his house arrest there during his imprisonment by Parliament.

Palatial Elizabethan country house in Derbyshire in the north Midlands of England, built between 1590 and 1597 by the wealthy Bess of Hardwick. Mentioned in the play, Charles the First. Now owned by the National Trust.
Hatton Garden is in the Holborn district of London. Center of the London jewelry trade since the medieval period.

place.placeName: Theatre Royal Haymarket, Westminster, London, England
place.note: Theatre in Westminster, London, on Suffolk Street in the West End. London’s third patent theater, after Covent Garden and Drury Lane. Originally built in 1720, farther north on the same street, it was relocated in 1821 to a building redesigned by John Nash as part of his renovations to the entire neighborhood.
Town on the Thames near the intersection of Oxfordshire, Berkshire and Buckinghamshire.
A county in south east England. The county town is Hertford.

Country house estate built around a thirteenth-century nunnery. During the dissolution of the monasteries, it was given to the Cromwell family and later became the estate of the Earls of Sandwich. From 1627, it was the estate of the Parliamentary army leader Sir Edward Montagu. Also spelled Hinchingbrooke. Now a Grade I listed building.
A district in central London between the West End and the City of London; now in the London borough of Camden.

A region of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. Until the Napoleonic invasion of 1795, part of the United Provinces of the Netherlands. After Napoleon abolished the Netherlands' historic Republic (founded in the sixteenth century), Holland gradually become colloquial for the Netherlands, and today the two geographic entities are frequently conflated. Charles II and other exiled Stuarts took refuge in Holland and France.

Built in Kensington in 1605 for Sir Walter Cope; later owned by the Rich and the Fox families. In Mitford’s time, it was a noted gathering place of the Holland House set of Whig notables. Now a Grade I listed building in London, it was firebombed during the Blitz in 1940, and only the east wing and part of the ground floor remain.

Country house estate in Holdenby, near Althorp, Northamptonshire where King Charles I was held captive in 1647 before being turned over to the Long Parliament. The original mansion, built in 1583, was almost entirely demolished in the seventeenth century; subsequent renovations have left little remaining of the original.
A channel that runs through Reading off the Kennet River.
City in Wales; a major Irish Sea port.

Historically, a four thousand acre tract of heathland outside London near Hounslow in the county of Middlesex, crossed by major routes between London and the west and southwest of England. In Mitford’s time, the heath was crossed by the Great West Road and the Bath Road and, as it had been in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, was still known as a dangerous spot for unwary travellers who might find themselves robbed by highwaymen or footpads. From at least the English Civil Wars until World War II, the heath has been used as a military staging area and training ground. Today, all that remains of the heath is two hundred acres preserved as parkland.
Central European country bordered by Slovakia, Ukraine, Romania, Serbia, Croatia, Slovenia, and Austria.

In Mitford’s time, the East India Company and its private armies controlled India and its economy, effectively from 1757 to 1858, after which Queen Victoria and her government directly governed India as the Raj. Became the Republic of India, a federal parliamentary republic, in 1950.
An island in the North Atlantic and part of the British Isles in Europe, which contains Great Britain and over six thousand smaller isles.

An island in the English Channel off the coast of Hampshire. Was earlier owned by a Norman family and a kingdom in its own right until 1293. Until 1890, it was part of the county of Hampshire, and it shared a Lord Lieutenant with that county until 1974. Until 1995, the island, like Jersey and Guernsey, also had a governor. The Island is now considered its own administrative county.
In Mitford’s time, the ancient lost kingdom of the Hebrews, known as the land of Israel. Now the State of Israel, a unitary parliamentary republic.
Country in south-central Europe; shaped as a peninsula that reaches deep into the Mediterranean Sea.

Ancient city sacred to Jews, Muslims, and Christians, and one of the oldest cities in the world. It is located in the Judaean Mountains, between the Dead Sea and the Mediterranean. Today, both the State of Israel and the State of Palestine claim the city as their capital.
A district of west London, now part of the Royal Boroughs of Chelsea and Kensington in inner London. Site of Kensington Palace, Kensington Gardens, and Holland Park.
State in the southeastern United States, originally part of Virginia.

Once a village northeast of Richmond, now a suburban district part of the London Borough of Richmond upon Thames. Site of what is now the Royal Botanic Gardens, a World Heritage Site, which includes Kew Palace, a royal residence favored by George III, and Kew Gardens.

place.placeName: Kings Bench Prison, Southwark, London, England
place.note: A prison in Southwark, south London, that took its name from the King’s Bench court of law, which heard cases of bankruptcy and other misdemeanors. In use from medieval times, during Mitford’s time it was often used as a debtor’s prison.

Region in northwest England famous for its lakes, forests, and mountains (or fells) and its associations with the early 19th century writings of William Wordsworth and the other Lake Poets or Lakers, as they were sometimes called. In Mitford’s time, the Lake District was spread across Cumberland, Westmorland, and Lancashire; the present-day Lake District is now entirely in Cumbria. The highest mountain in England, Scafell Pike, lies within this region, as do the deepest and longest lakes in England, Wastwater and Windermere.
County town of Lancashire, on the river Lune.

Site of La Trappe Abbey, the house of origin of the Order of Cistercians of the Strict Observance (O.C.S.O.: Ordo Cisterciensis Strictioris Observantiae), Reformed Cistercians or Trappists, to whom it gave its name.
City in the East Midlands of England, and the county town of Leicestershire. The city lies on the River Soar.
County in the north east of England. Its county town is Lincoln.
The capital city of Portugal, located on the western Iberian peninsula; one of the oldest cities in the world.

District in the City of Westminster, London, west of Regent’s Park. Student artists and painters from the Royal Academy lived in this district in the early nineteenth century, including William Blake, Richard Cosway, and Benjamin Robert Haydon. Also the name of a road in the district.
Small parish that runs from Ilsley Downs to the Vale of White Horse district; historically part of Berkshire and now in Oxfordshire.
Tributary of the Thames that flows 28 miles northward from Basingstoke through Swallowfield, Shinfield to Wargrave. The river has for centuries been a location for milling operations.

Capital city of England and the United Kingdom; one the oldest cities in Western Europe. Major seaport and global trading center at the mouth of the Thames. From 1831 to 1925, the largest city in the world.

Originally located in London's Exchange Alley district, a site of commerce in the seveneteenth and eighteenth centuries. Formally established in 1801 in Sweeting's Alley; from 1802 to 1972, it was located in Capel Court. Precursor to the present-day London Stock Exchange, now located in Paternoster Square.

A hill in the City of London and the site of St. Paul’s Cathedral. It is one of the three ancient hills of London. The old city gate and attached gaol were removed in 1780. During Mitford’s lifetime, the street of the same name had not yet been built; a narrower roadway called Ludgate Street stood in its place.
Resort town on the coast in west Dorset. The Mitfords lived here for about a year from 1795 to 1797. One of the settings in Jane Austen’s Persuasion.
The farmhouse whose inhabitants Mitford recalls in A Great Farmhouse.
Abbreviation used for the area in which the great farmhouse is located, from the sketch of the Our Village sketch of the same name.
Capital of Spain.

place.placeName: Magdalen College, Oxford University, Oxford, Oxfordshire, England
place.note: One of the constituent colleges of Oxford University.

place.placeName: Manchester House, 29 Imperial Road, Exmouth, Devon, England
place.note: Mitford dates her opening poem in the Journal from this location in January 1819. Now called Chester House, it was once the home of Mary Ann Clarke.
Town in Buckinghamshire on the Thames. Mitford’s friends Mr. Johnson and Miss Johnson resided near here.
Meadows belonging to the Bertram House estate.
Meadows owned by Mr. Bridgewater. One of the locations Mitford goes cowslipping in April 1820.
Meadows owned by Mr. Davies. One of the locations Mitford goes to gather woodsorrel and violets.
Meadows near the cottage at Three Mile Cross.
Meillerie is a village on the shores of Lake Geneva, in southeastern France.
Country between the United States and Central America.

Ancient Northern Italian city, elevated into a duchy in 1395. During the fifteenth century, the Duchy of Milan was frequently at war with Venice. In Mitford's lifetime, Milan and Lombardy were part of the Austrian empire until Napoleon invaded Italy in 1796, after which Milan became successively, capital of the Cisalpine republic and capital of the Kingdom of Italy, as part of the French empire. The Congress of Vienna returned Milan to the Austrian empire in 1815. Nationalist independence movements in the mid-19th century, supported by Napoleon III, resulted in the construction of a unified Kingdom of Italy in 1861.

place.placeName: New Mint, Little Tower Hill, London, England
place.note: A new Royal Mint was built on Little Tower Hill beginning in 1805, once space had run out at the previous Mint location at the Tower of London, which also served as an armoury during this period. The new site provided a dedicated location for coining British currency and made use of the latest steam-powered minting machinery. The buildings were completed by 1809, the machinery tested by 1811 and the new Mint opened officially in 1812. Several prints of the new Mint appear between 1811 and 1813.
Village east of Swallowfield. George Mitford and his friends go coursing there.
Village in Berkshire located seven miles south-west of Reading.
Sacred mountain of classical Greek antiquity.
Grand Duchy of Moscow, known in English as Muscovy. A medieval Rus’ principality centered on Moscow, the forerunner of the state of Russia under the Tsars, sometimes called the Tsardom of Muscovy.

Capital city of the Kingdom of Naples from 1282 to 1816. Then the capital of the Two Sicilies from 1816 to 1861 until the unification of Italy. Now capital city of the Campania region of Italy. One of the oldest cities in the world.
Village in Northamptonshire, the site of the Battle of Naseby on 14 June 1645, the decisive Parliamentary victory in the English Civil War.

place.placeName: New York City, New York, USA
place.note: Most populous city in the United States, founded as a trading post by the Dutch Republic in the seventeenth century. An important trading port and center of slavery in the eighteenth century. A key site in the War of American Independence and the first capital of the new Republic. During Mitford’s lifetime, the city developed into an important literary and publishing center; during the 1830s and 1840s Washington Irving, Herman Melville, and Nathaniel Parker Willis all lived in New York.
Market town on the River Kennet in Berkshire. Horseracing took place between 1805 and 1811 at the Newbury Races, although the current racecourse did not come into existence until 1905.
Newman Street in London. Barbara Hofland’s address in the 1820s was 23 Newman Street. It is located between Oxford Street and Mortimer Street, east of Bedford Square in North London.

County in north east England. County town is Alnwick. George Mitford was a descendant of an aristocratic family from Northumberland. George Mitford took Mary to visit relations in Northumberland in 1806.

Oakhampton House is a country estate in Dunley, owned by the descendants of Royalist Sir Richard Crane during Mitford’s time. Sir William Elford was staying at this address in April 1821. More research needed.

Large parish. In 1831, the Hundred of Overton contained Ashe, Bradley, Deane, Laverstoke, Overton, Tadley, and North Waltham. Overton Mill has produced banknote paper since the eighteenth century. Richard Russell lived here as vicar of Overton and rector of Ashe and Deane.

Oxford Circuit was one of six assize circuits in England and Wales. Before 1830, the Oxford Circuit consisted of the counties of Oxford, Worcester, Stafford, Salop, Hereford, Monmouth, Gloucester, and Berkshire. Judges were appointed by the monarch and traveled the Circuit twice per year to hear trials of serious crimes. Talfourd was appointed to the Oxford Circuit in 1821.
County town of Oxfordshire, in the south east of England about twenty-five miles from Reading. Site of Oxford University.

place.placeName: University of Oxford, Oxford, Oxfordshire, England
place.note: Research university made up of constituent colleges; considered the oldest university in the English-speaking world. Founded sometime around 1096 and located in Oxford.
A county in south east England. Location of Oxford University and Blenheim Palace.

place.placeName: Painted Chamber, Westminster Palace, Westminster, London, England
place.note: A room in Westminster Palace destroyed during the accidental burning of the Houses of Parliament in 1834.

In Mitford's time, refers not to a country, but to the geographic region in Western Asia known as the Land of Israel or Holy Land referred to in the Christian Bible, comprising the present-day state of Israel, the Palestinian territories, and parts of Jordan. Similar names were used in the ancient world, and the region was later the Roman province of Syria Palaestina. It also refers to the southern section of broader regional designations such as Canaan or the Levant.

Forest in north Hampshire, near Silchester. Today, Pamber Forest and Silchester Common together form a Site of Special Scientific Interest; Pamber Forest is managed as a local Nature Reserve. The woodland encompasses a hazel coppice dominated by oak standards and contains over forty plant species rare or uncommon in the UK.
