Capital of France and important center of trade, banking, publishing, fashion, and artistic and scientific activity. Center of Enlightenment activity in the eighteenth century. A key site in the French Revolution and Napoleonic Wars; travel between London and Paris was much restricted during this period.

Founded in the seventeenth century as the capital of the Pennsylvania colony and later the capital of the state. It played a key role in the American Revolution and served as one-time capital of the Republic before the capital moved to Washington, D.C. In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, an important center of publishing, and of artistic, literary, and scientific thought. During the nineteenth century, an important destination for immigrants from Europe as well as for African-American migrants.

A wide road in London’s West End that lends its name to the surrounding district. Since medieval times, Piccadilly had been known as the road to Reading. In Mitford’s time, it was the site of many inns and public houses, including the White Horse coaching inn, which was the starting terminus for western-bound mailcoaches bound for Bath and Bristol. It was also the location of Devonshire House, 18th-century headquarters for the Whig party, and Burlington House, later home to the Royal Academy of Arts, the Geological Society of London, and the Royal Astronomical Society. It was also the headquarters for booksellers such as Stockdale and Hatchards in this period.
Plantations--planted woodlands--belonging to the Bertram House estate. One location where Mitford went firtopping and fed my robins in winter 1819 and 1820.

City on the coast of Devonshire. After declines in the seventeenth century, increasingly important from the late eighteenth century into the nineteenth as a seaport, site of trade and emigration to and from the Americas, and a center of shipbuilding. Birthplace of Benjamin Robert Haydon. Sir William Elford was also born nearby at Bickham. Elford worked as a banker at Plymouth Bank (Elford, Tingcombe and Purchase) in Plymouth, from its founding in 1782, and he was elected a member of Parliament for Plymouth and served from 1796 to 1806.

Also known as the Portsmouth Block Mills, established in 1802 by Marc Isambard Brunel. Factories in the Portsmouth dockyard that produced pulley blocks for Royal Navy ships’ rigging. The Mills were the site of the world’s first mass production line and used all-metal machine tools.
Thomas Noon Talfourd’s address in London, in the Temple district; Mitford addressed letters to him at 1 Pump Court. Pump Court is west off Middle Temple Lane, north of the Inner Temple.

City in the province of Ravenna, Emilia-Romagna region on the north east coast of Italy on the Adriatic Sea. Lord Byron lived in Ravenna from 1819-1821, which was the site of his love affair with Teresa Guiccioli, and where he composed The Two Foscari in the summer of 1821.

County town in Berkshire, in the Thames valley at the confluence of the Thames and the River Kennet. The town developed as a river port and in Mitford’s time served as a staging point on the Bath Road and was developing into a center of manufacturing. Mitford lived here with her parents from 1791 to 1795, on Coley Avenue in the parish of St. Mary’s and attended the Abbey School. The family returned to Reading from 1797 to about 1804, after which they relocated to Bertram House. They frequently visited Reading thereafter from their homes at nearby Bertram House, Three Mile Cross and Swallowfield. Mitford later used scenes from Reading as the basis for Belford Regis; or Sketches of a Country Town.

Public grammar school originally founded as a Reading Abbey school, which dates to 1125, located in Reading. Dr. Richard Valpy was headmaster from 1754 to 1836 and was then succeeded by his son. Talfourdwas a pupil there. Mitford wrote reviews for the Reading Mercury of the plays performed there by the pupils as part of the triennial Oxford School Visitations.
Theater in Reading. Exact location unknown. More research needed.

place.placeName: The Red Cow Inn, Reading, Berkshire, England
place.note: Located in Reading. Likely the location listed in Horniman’s Directory (1827) at 50 Crown Street run by John Easby or Easebey. The Red Cow is still in operation at the corner of Southampton and Crown Streets.

Now an upscale neighborhood in north London, Regent’s Park is named for the Royal Park it encompasses. The district was developed after 1811 when the Prince Regent commissioned John Nash to create a plan for the area. The Park was made part of Nash’s larger plans for nearby Regent Street and Carlton House Terrace. The Park’s residential terraces and Inner Circle villas were built during the early nineteenth century, and the Park was opened to the public in 1835. Also the site of the London Zoo (or Regent’s Zoo), created in 1828 for scientific study and opened to the public in 1847.
Second largest river in central and western Europe; begins in the southeastern Swiss Alps and eventually empties into the North Sea in the Netherlands.
Oldest of four bridges spanning the Grand Canal in Venice.
Richmond upon Thames, now a borough of London, formerly part of Surrey. The Hoflands lived there and Thomas Hofland painted views of the area.

City on the central Italian Peninsula on the River Tiber. One of the oldest cities in the world, and once capital of the ancient Roman Empire. Throughout much of Mitford’s lifetime, Rome was governed by the Vatican as part of the Papal States, although it was part of the short-lived Roman Republic between 1798 and 1800, annexed to the French Empire under Napoleon between 1808 and 1814, and experienced another short-lived attempt at Italian unification in 1849. Center of art and culture since ancient times, Rome was a frequent stop for young men from Western Europe on the Grand Tour. Now the capital of Italy and of the Lazio region.
Town described in the Our Village story, Lucy as a beautiful, Roman-walled town, and mentioned as the eventual residence of Lucy after her marriage. Probably Silchester.
Seaport in northern Italy. Pope Pius VII and his Cardinals were driven to exile here by Napoleon, between 1809 and 1813.
Country that occupies the northern third of the island of Great Britain. Part of the United Kingdom.
The 481-mile long river that flows from northeastern France through Paris, Le Havre/Honfleur, and into the English Channel.

Village in Hampshire in present-day South Downs National Oark. Gilbert White made his natural observations here when writing A Naturalist's Calendar and The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne.
Artificial body of water, created in 1730 that occupies 40 acres in .
Home of Mr. Johnsonand Miss Johnson, until Mr. Johnson’s death in 1821. Near Great Marlow in Buckinghamshire.

Location where Mary Queen of Scots was held captive in 1568 by order of Queen Elizabeth I. Here, Mary was guarded by George Talbot, the Sixth Earl of Shrewsbury, and his wife, Elizabeth Talbot or Bess of Hardwick befriended the royal captive. There are no standing remains of the castle, since the site has been covered over by a market district. Only partial foundations have been discovered during the excavation and renovations for buildings in the area.

Village and parish south of Reading in Berkshire. Shinfield parish encompasses Mitford’s homes at Bertram House and at her cottage in Three Mile Cross. George and Mary Mitford are buried here in the parish church.

Shinfield parish is located in the county of Berkshire and contains Three Mile Cross, Spencer's Wood, Grazeley, and the village of Shinfield. Many of Mitford's sketches are set in and around the parish.

Village in Hampshire, approximately nine miles from Reading, on the Berkshire county border, known for its Roman ruins. It is featured in several stories in Our Village, sometimes by name, sometimes through the abbreviation S.

Part of the Roman ruins near the town of Silchester. Calleva Atrebatum began as an Iron Age settlement and capital of the Atrebates tribe. During the Roman occupation, the village developed into a walled town with ampitheater in the province of Britannia, remains of which are still visible. The site is managed today by English Heritage.

Major London thoroughfare now in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. Runs between Knightsbridge and Sloane Square. Sloane Street takes its name from Sir Hans Sloane, who purchased the surrounding area in 1712.

A square in the Soho district of London. It was originally called King Square after Charles II, whose statue still stood in the square’s garden in Mitford’s time. According to Mitford, Charles Kemble and his wife lived in Soho Square in the 1820s.

Large neoclassical public building in central London on the Strand, overlooking the River Thames. In Mitford’s time, the site of Royal Academy exhibitions and other cultural events. A building designed and built by Sir William Chambers beginning in 1776 in order to house public offices which had previously been scattered around London in older buildings. Likely not completed until after 1819. This building’s North Wing faced the Strand and also included East and West Wings of the present-day quadrangle. Housed the Royal Academy of Arts, the Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge, and the Society of Antiquaries until the 1870s. Sometimes a metonym for the Royal Academy; Mitford mentions in letter of 23 November 1821 to Elford that she hopes he will send his picture to Somerset House.
County in southwest England, now known as Somerset. County town is Taunton.
Southampton is a major port city in the county of Hampshire on the south coast of England, near the New Forest.

Village south of Reading that adjoins Three Mile Cross to the north and lying east of Grazeley. Until 1844, within Hampshire. In Mitford's time, the location, not of a wood, but an open common, which was entirely enclosed by 1864.

An archipelago in the east of Indonesia that, from the sixteenth to the nineteenth centuries, was a center for the culture of cloves, mace, and nutmeg for colonizing Asian and European powers. From 1667 to 1942, the region was largely a part of the Dutch empire. The region was briefly under the control of the British from 1796 to 1802 and again in 1810 to 1817. During the British occupation, they uprooted plantstock for removal to other British colonies, in order to break the Dutch monopoly on spices such as nutmeg.

Village five km west of Versailles in France, where Françoise d’ Aubigné died; she founded Maison royle de Saint-Louis there, a school for poor girls of the artistocracy. Now the Saint-Cyr-l’École, Yvelines, in the western suburbs of Paris.

place.placeName: Church of St. James, Bramley, Hampshire, England
place.note: Church located in Bramley, Hampshire that dates from the twelfth century, undergoing many renovations since that time. The church is notable for its beautiful stained glass and its elaborate marble tomb sculpture of Bernard Brocas. It is featured in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying, when the narrator and her companion take a tour. Today, it is a Grade I listed building.

place.placeName: St. John's Wood, Westminster, London, England
place.note: A district in the City of Westminster, London, historically part of Marylebone. The area was being developed in Mitford's time as a suburban residential area. Location of Lord's Cricket Ground.

place.placeName: St. Lawrence Church, Reading, Berkshire, England
place.note: Ancient church on Friar Street in Reading. During Mitford’s time, it was the parish church. Spelled variously Lawrence or Laurence. The Valpy family’s parish church; Dr. Richard Valpy’s students placed a marble bust of him in the church after his death, although he is buried elsewhere. Mitford refers to this church as St. John’s Church in Our Village.
The main public square in Venice, known as Piazza St. Marco. It is bounded on the eastern end by St. Mark’s Basilica.

place.placeName: St. Michael’s Church, St. Albans, Hertfordshire, England
place.note: A parish church in St. Albans, a city in Hertfordshire, England.

place.placeName: St. James’s Street, Westminster, London, England
place.note: The main thoroughfare in the district of St James’s in central London which runs from Piccadilly downhill to St James’s Palace at its southern end. The area was named after a hospital dedicated to St. James the Less. In Mitford’s time, St. James Street was the home of many of the best-known clubs, such as Brooke’s and White’s.

place.placeName: St. John’s Place, Lisson Grove, Regent’s Park, London, England
place.note: Occasional residence from 1817 onward of Benjamin Robert Haydon in Lisson Grove, Regent’s Park, London. Site of Haydon’s famous dinner gathering with guests William Wordsworth, John Keats, Charles Lamb, Thomas Monkhouse, and Joseph Ritchie on 28 December 1817. Haydon’s enormous painting, Christ’s Entry into Jerusalem hung in Haydon’s painting room as background.

placeName.addName: Cathedral Church of St. Paul the Apostle

place.note: St Paul’s Cathedral, London, is a Church of England (Anglican) cathedral, the seat of the Bishop of London, and the mother church of the Diocese of London. It sits on Ludgate Hill at the highest point of the City of London. The present church, by Sir Christopher Wren, was built after the Great Fire of London in the late seventeenth century. The building would have dominated the London skyline in Mitford’s time. The state funerals of Lord Nelson and the Duke of Wellington were held at St. Paul’s.

place.placeName: St. Quintin School, 22 Hans Place, Chelsea, London, England
place.note: Public school for girls founded by French emigre M. St. Quintin (or Quentin), a friend of George Mitford and of Dr. Richard Valpy. It was originally located in Reading, moved to London (at 22 Hans Place, in Chelsea), and later relocated to Paris. Frances Rowden was schoolmistress there, and Mitford was a pupil at the London location, as were Landon and Caroline Ponsonby Lamb. The majority of the houses in Hans Place were substantially rebuilt in the late nineteenth century; the building that housed the school no longer stands.

A major street in central London that became a gathering place for writers and thinkers in the nineteenth-century and that marks the southern boundary of the West End theatre district, which made it a hub of the nineteenth-century theatre world as well.
Village in Hampshire, England. Alternative spellings are: Strathfieldsaye, Stratford Saye, and Stratford Sea. In Mitford’s time, the Duke of Wellington moved there.
A market town in Warwickshire, England, on the River Avon, best known as the birthplace of Shakespeare.
Horace Walpole’s house at Strawberry Hill, near Twickenham.

Estate acquired through marriage by the second Earl of Clarendon. The estate sits where the Rivers Loddon and Blackwater join. The estate had been the property of the Backhouse family, who occupied an old Tudor mansion that was renovated and modernized. Swallowfield Park was subsequently sold by Hyde's son, the third earl, to Thomas Diamond Pitt, great-grandfather of William Pitt the younger. He had made his fortune in India, famously by the purchase and sale of a large diamond to the Regent of France. The Swallowfield estate remained in the Pitt family until 1737 when it was sold to John Dodd. In 1783, Dodd's descendents sold it to Sylvanus Bevan, whose descendents sold it in turn in 1788 to Timothy Hare Earle, Esq. By Mitford's time, the estate had passed to Earle's son, Timothy Hare Altabon Earle. As a result of financial losses the latter had suffered in the West Indies on account of the abolition of British participation in the slave trade, he sold Swallowfield in 1820 to Sir Henry Russell. Sir Henry had recently returned to England, having spent 1798 to 1814 in India. By 1825, Sir Henry began making renovations to the property, together with his son, Henry, who himself inherited Swallowfield in 1836. Mitford developed a close friendship with Lady Marie Clotilde Russell, his wife.
Swallowfield and Its Owners by Lady Constance Russell
Swallowfield Park, Berkshire by Margot Finn
Village in Berkshire, where Mary Russell Mitford moved to a cottage in 1851, three miles south of her long-time home at Three Mile Cross.

place.placeName: Swan Inn, Three Mile Cross, Berkshire, England
place.note: A seventeenth-century public house and coaching inn next to which the Mitford family lived in Three Mile Cross. It is featured in Our Village as the Rose Inn.
A country located in western-Central Europe.

District in central London, traditional location for barristers’ chambers and other offices for legal practice, with its four Inns of Court. The Inner Temple, one of the four Inns of Court, was responsible for training and licensing barristers. Talfourd had chambers in this neighborhood, although not in the Inner Temple, and Mitford addressed letters to him there.
The longest river in England, the Thames has its source in Gloucestershire and flows through Reading, Oxford, Windsor, and London into the Thames Estuary to the North Sea.

Village and parish near Reading on the River Kennet, later part of the Kennet and Avon Canal system. From the 17th century, a coach stop on the road from London to Bath and Bristol. From 1847, a stop on the London to Exeter railway line and from 1852 to 1963, a stop on the Berks and Hants Railway, a subsidiary of the Great Western Railway.

place.placeName: Holy Trinity Church, Theale, Berkshire, England
place.note: Anglican church built to replace a modest brick chapel built by clergyman Dr. Sheppard, who held the living of the entire parish of Tilehurst. Church, rectory, and school built in memory of Dr. Sheppard by his wife Sophia Routh Sheppard and her brother Martin Routh. Building began shortly after Dr. Sheppard's death in 1814, but the church was not completed and consecreated until August 21, 1832, although Mitford speaks of the new church in 1827.

In the ancient world, the militarily strategic location of a narrow passage to the Malian Gulf in coastal Greece. Notable for its hot sulphur springs, which gave rise to its name referncing the hot Gates of Hades in Greek mythology. The location of the Battle of Thermopylae.

The Battle of Thermopylae, fought in 480 BC, saw a heavily outnumbered Greek army defeated by the invading Persian army. Over the course of a week, the Greeks held off the Persians while exacting a devastating death toll from them until, finally, the rearguard of the Greek army that had been left to defend the strategically important pass of Thermopylae was defeated. The Battle of Thermopylae might be metaphorically invoked as shorthand for a noble though inevitable defeat, although given the heavy losses sustained by the victorious Persian army, the battle might also be invoked as an example of a Pyrrhic victory.
Village in the parish of Shinfield in Berkshire, where Mary Russell Mitford moved with her parents in 1820. They lived in a cottage there until 1851.
Market town near the River Dart in Devonshire, and residence of Sir William Elford, who lived there after 1831 at The Priory, the house of his daughter (Elizabeth) and son-in-law.
City in France on the lower part of the River Loire.

Dating from the Norman Conquest of England, this famous complex of fortified towers was begun by William the Conqueror in 1066 and used variously as a royal residence, an armory, a treasury, a menagerie, and a prison. In Mitford’s time, a tourist attraction admired for its Gothic architecture, which included the Royal Menagerie, displays of armour, and the Crown Jewels; it was also an active armoury and the home of the Royal Mint until the early nineteenth-century.

Ancient seaport in North Africa, now the capital and largest city in Libya. In the eighteenth and early nineteenth century, the city was nominally under control of the Ottoman Empire but was de facto ruled by Turkish Janissary officers between 1714 and 1835, after which the Ottoman Empire reasserted control. During the period of Janissary rule, Tripoli was a base of operations for piracy (Barbary pirates), blackmail schemes, and demands for tribute as protection against piracy, which led to the first and second Barbary Wars with the United States in the early nineteenth century.

place.placeName: Twickenham, Richmond upon Thames, London, England
place.note: Twickenham, a town on the Thames, now part of Greater London. In the eighteenth century, the home of Alexander Pope and Horace Walpole, who built a neo-Gothic mansion at Strawberry Hill.
A department in southeast France, named after the Fontaine-de-Vaucluse, a famous spring.

Department in western France, traditionally believed to be the birthplace of Elinor of Acquitaine. During the French Revolution, the Vendee mounted a fierce resistance to the revolutionary government and later refused to recognize Napoleon's legitimacy after his escape from Elba.

An Italian city, consisting of 118 islands in the Venetian lagoon and located in the northeastern region of Italy. Founded in 697that, until 1797, existed as a sovereign republic with an elected leader known as the doge. At its height, the Republic of Venice included the Veneto region of what is now Italy, the Fruili-Venezia Giulia region that encompasses parts of present-day Austria and Slovenia, and the Istria Peninsula. Napoleon's 1797 Italian campaign brought the millenia-long period of Venetian independence to an end. It did not become part of the Kingdom of Italy until 1866, after Mitford's death. Venice (and Italian settings more generally) were notably popular amongst British Romantic authors, especially Lord Byron, Percy Shelley, Mary Russell Mitford, as well as authors of Gothic novels.

This minor theatre opened in 1818 on the south side of Waterloo bridge, in order to capitalize on the increase of traffic expected from the new bridge. It was purchased in 1833 by Daniel Egerton and William Abbott
who renamed it the Royal Victoria Theatre. It was not named after the young Princess Victoria, then fourteen, but after her mother, Victoria, Duchess of Kent. Mitford’s play Charles I was performed here. Still an active producing theater, called The Old Vic.

Capital and the largest city in Austria. Historically, a center for music in Europe. During Mitford’s time, Vienna became the capital of the Austrian Empire (in 1804, during the Napoleonic Wars) and hosted the Congress of Vienna in 1814-1815.
Coastal city in northwest Spain near the Portuguese border.

A steep, corkscrew-like hill described in A Great Farmhouse on which the farmer's greyhound, Helen proudly kills an old hare. This might be a mappable place in England, but further research is needed.
Located in the United Kingdom; a country in southwest Great Britain.

Warwick Gaol was a functioning county jail located next to a town building that would later grow to be Shire Hall. The jail remained open until the late eighteenth century, when it was condemned by reformer John Howard.
Municipality in Belgium, south of Brussels. The battle of Waterloo, at which Napoleon was defeated in 1815, was fought south of the municipality, at Braine-l’Alleud.

Small market town on the edge of the Chiltern Hills. By the late eighteenth century, it had six inns, all owned by the Hayward brewing family. Watlington Town Hall, built in 1665, is a Grade II listed building.

placeName.addName: Collegiate Church of St. Peter at Westminster

place.note: Gothic style church in Westminster, London, where English monarchs have traditionally been crowned and buried since 1066. Many important literary and historical figures are recognized with memorials throughout this famous abbey. The present structure began construction in 1245 by King Henry III and the two western towers were added in the early eighteenth century.

place.placeName: Palace of Westminster, Westminster, London, England
place.note: Located in Westminster, London, along the Thames River. This is the meeting place of England’s two Houses of Parliament.

In Mitford’s time, a district of Greater London and the location of St. James's Palace, Buckingham Palace, and the Houses of Parliament; of shopping districts around Bond Street, Regent Street, and Oxford Street; and of the fashionable residential and theater districts of the West End. Historically a separate entity west of the City of London, now an inner London borough centrally located in Greater London. The site of Westminster Abbey and the Palace of Westminster. Westminster has served as the seat of English government since the eleventh-century reign of King Edward the Confessor. Until the sixteenth century, Westminster was geographically separated from London by relatively undeveloped acreage. After this space was built up, in 1604, the City and Liberty of Westminster was established by James I.
To be developed with further research. Could be the same as Whitby Park. See notes on insolvency court claim, the Jurist, 1837

Location of Mr. and Mrs. Newell's farm in St. Giles parish, Berkshire, likely the model for the great farmhouse at M. in A Great Farmhouse. Could be the same as Whitby Hill, but this needs further research.

The word Whitehall, used without specific reference to the palace, refers metonymically to the centers of power of the English government, including the monarchy and parliament. Literally, Whitehall is a road in Westminster, running from Trafalgar Square to Parliament Square, which takes its name from Whitehall Palace on its route.

Main London residence of English monarchs from 1530 until 1698, when a major part of the palace was destroyed by fire. During the seventeenth century, renovations made it the largest palace in Europe. Site of the execution of King Charles I.

Berkshire estate of George Spencer-Churchill, the sixth Duke of Marlborough. Purchased by him in 1798 and extensively renovated at great expense until the Duke’s bankruptcy in 1819, when the estate and contents were sold at auction. Subject of an 1818 publication by the Hoflands. Formerly the manor of Earley Whiteknights; now Whiteknights Park, part of the campus of the University of Reading.
Hamlet near Reading.
A landlocked county that borders Berkshire, Gloucesteshire, Oxfordshire, Hampshire, Somerset, Hampshire, and Dorset. It encompasses Old Sarum, Salisbury, Salisbury Plain, and the Stonehenge site.

City and county town of Hampshire. Site of Winchester Cathedral and Winchester College, one of the oldest public grammar schools. Jane Austen died here and is buried in the Cathedral. John Keats wrote several of his best-known poems while on a visit to the city.

One of two longest and deepest lakes in England, in the Lake District, located near the town of the same name, now in the County of Cumbria and part of the Lake District National Park. Historically, the lake made up part of the border between the counties of Westmorland and Lancashire.

The largest and the oldest-occupied castle in the world, Windsor Castle was built by William the Conqueror (William I) circa 1070, with the presently-existing buildings commissioned by Henry II, Henry III and Edward III. During Mitford's lifetime, Windsor Castle saw a series of renovations under George III, George IV, and became one of the primary residences of the British royal family. From 1810 on, George IIIwas confined to the State Apartments at the Castle during his illness.

Market town in Berkshire, about twenty miles from Reading and twenty miles from Charing Cross. Location of royal residence Windsor Castle. British royals resumed an active presence in Windsor after 1778, when George III began use of Queen’s Lodge, and continued with use of the Castle after 1804. Two new army barracks were built in the town in the early nineteenth century.

Estate purchased by the Bernard Brocas shortly before his death in 1777, and extensively renovated by his wife, Harriet. In the Our Village story, Bramley Maying, Mitford mentions W. Park, which may refer to Wokefield Park.
A market town in south east England in Berkshire, near Reading. The Mitfords sometimes travelled to Wokingham on their way to London, or to visit the home of their friends, the Webbs.
Could refer to Woodcock Lane in either Wokingham or Reading. This entry may change with further research.
Historic county in northern England and the largest county in the United Kingdom. Abbreviated Yorks.

Fictional Forest of Arden, setting for As You Like It. Variously identified with historical and fictional representations of the Forest of Ardennes in continental Europe, as well as with Arden, a heavily wooded area of Warwickshire, England.
Fictional country populated by giantsin Swift’s novel Gulliver’s Travels.
Fictional setting of Spenser's Faerie Queen.
Fictional island of which Sancho Panza is awarded governorship in Don Quixote.

A fictional nation in Central America that the Scottish soldier and con artist Gregor MacGregor invented in order to scam unwitting investors. MacGregor, who engaged in an astonishing level of world-building and document forgery as he devised a parliament, military uniforms, and economic system for Poyais, tricked hundreds of people into investing in the fictional country's bonds. Appoximately 250 people emigrated to Poyais between 1822 and 1823, but when they arrived in what turned out to be Honduras (which had only just declared independence from Spainin 1821), they found themselves in a jungle. More than half of these emigrants ended up dying, and fewer than 50 ever made it back to the British isles.
Fictional island settled by the shipwrecked Prospero in The Tempest.
An elevated ridge where the Our Village narrator and her friends climb in donkey carts and by foot in Cousin Mary. It may be the Finchamstead Ridges.
Fictional island in Robinson Crusoe.
The Rose Inn is mentioned many times as the local inn in Our Village. It is based on the real-life Swan Inn, next to which the Mitfords lived in Three Mile Cross.
Fictional name used in Our Village for St. Lawrence Church, an ancient church in Reading.

River in ancient Greek mythology that separates the realms of the living from the dead, and encircling Hades (the realm of the dead or underworld). For more, see the reference in Encyclopedia Mythica:
Mentioned in the Our Village story, Bramley Maying, and probably refers to Wokefield Park.

item.name: common European adder
Vipera berus berus
Vipera
Viperidae
item.note: Venomous snake widespread throughout Eurasia and the UK. They are not particularly dangerous to humans; they are not aggressive and bites are seldom fatal. Also called the cross adderfor the diamond patterns on its back, although melanated individuals may appear entirely brown-black with no visible patterning. One of three snakes native to the UK; the other two are nonvenmous: the barred grass snake and the smooth snake. They have adapted to a wide range of land habitats such as meadows, rough commons and hedgerows, and the edges of woodlands, although they require complex habitats to support basking, hunting for small mammals, amphibians, and insects; protection from predators, and hibernation. The name is derived from the generic word for serpent in Germanic languages, the same term used for snakes and the Devil in the Old Testament. The myth of the deaf adder has its source in Psalms 58: 4 and became proverbial for someone willfully refusing to hear by the early 17th century.

item.name: ant
Lasius niger
Lasius
Formicidae
item.note: Small, mostly wingless social insect. Symbolic of hard work, prudence, and foresight in Aesop's fable, The Grasshopper and the Ant.

item.name: Arabian horse
Equus ferus caballus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: A breed known for its stamina and athleticism, as well as its fine bone structure, arched neck, and highly-carried tail, were developed on the Arabian peninsula. The breed likely arrived in Europe around the time of the Crusades, as spoils of war, and became part of state and royal studs. James I introduced the breed to England in 1616 and others were imported in the 18th century to create modern racing breeds such as the English thoroughbred. Marengo, Napoleon's war horse, was an Arabian. Europeans travelling to the middle East in the 19th century began intensively collecting Arabians.

item.name: bee
Apis
item.note: Social insect collecting nectar to produce wax and honey. Both honeybees and bumblebees are common in the UK. Proverbial for busy and diligent workers, as in the Isaac Watts poem, Against Idleness and Mischief.

item.name: common blackbird
Turdus merula
Turdus
Turdidae
item.note: Medium-sized black member of the thrush family, with a yellow-orange bill and distinctive yellow ring around its eye. Widely distributed across Eurasia and North Africa; unrelated to New World blackbirds.

item.name: butterfly
item.note: Insect of the order Lepidoptera with two pairs of large wings that are covered with tiny scales, usually brightly colored, and typically held erect when at rest.

item.name: cat
Felis catus
Felis
Felidae
item.note: Now, as in Mitford's time, cats may be classed as domestic (kept as companion animals and for indoor pest control), farm (kept outdoors and in barns or even on ships for rodent control), or feral (wild). Domesticated around 7500 B.C. in Western Asia and likely brought to England by the Romans or other early traders. While frequently kept for rodent control, cats did not become common companion animals in England until the eighteenth century. British Shorthair and Scottish fold breeds are considered to have originated in the UK. Around 1819, the Mitfords owned a tabby named Poll and a long-haired white cat name Selim, likely a Turkish Angora.

item.name: chicken
Gallus domesticus
Gallus
Phasianidae
item.note: Domesticated birds kept as livestock and used for meat, eggs, and feathers. Descended from species of Southeast Asian wild junglefowl. First domesticated for ceremonial use and cockfighting, then kept for food in the Middle East and then in Europe, beginning about the 4th century B.C.

item.name: cow
Bos taurus
Bos
Bovidae
item.note: Large domesticated grazing animal raised as livestock for meat, milk, or hides. Cow is the term for female cattle and bull for males, although both are commonly referred to as cows. Also used as draught animals (called oxen) to pull carts or plows. One of the earliest domesticated animals, descended from two separate areas, one in the Near East (Turkey and northern Syria) and one in modern-day Pakistan. Many modern-day breeds are descended from cattle exported from the UK to the rest of the world between the l7th and early 20th century, including: Aberdeen Angus, Ayrshire, Belted Galloway, Blue Grey, Devon, Dexter, British White, British Friesian, English Longhorn, Gloucester, Guernsey, Hereford, Jersey, Kerry, and Shorthorn.

item.name: cricket
Gryllus campestris
Gryllus
Gryllidae
item.note: A dark-colored flightless cricket found in dry grasslands and heathlands. In Mitford's time, common in the UK and Western Europe; currently the most endangered cricket in the UK, due to habitat loss, mainly surviving in southern England. Scaly crickets and several species of bush crickets are also found in the UK. Symbolically associated with good luck. Mitford generally uses the simple term cricket.

item.name: common cuckoo
Cuculus canorus
Cuculus
Cuculidae
item.note: Migratory medium-sized blue-gray bird with long tail and wings that arrives in the UK in early spring. They are brood parasites who lay their eggs in the nest of other birds; they became proverbial for usurpers. Wordsworth published a poem To Cuckoo in 1807.

item.name: deer
Cervidae
item.note: Medium-sized hoofed mammals. Scottish red and roe deer are native to the UK, and European fallow deer are believed to the have been introduced by the Normans--all three species would have been extant in Mitford's time.

item.name: fallow deer
Cervus dama
Dama
Cervidae
item.note: A medium-sized animal with light red-brown fur, paler rump and tail, and branching antlers. Native to Turkey and likely also the Italian and Balkan peninsulas, spread throughout Europe by the Romans and imported into the UK with the Normans and then naturalized. Widespread throughout the southern UK and considered part of a different genus than the red deer or roe deer. The male is called a buck and the female a doe. Hunted and farmed for meat (venison), hair, hide, and antlers, they may also be kept in deer parks. An adaptable species that can survive on smaller tracts of woodland, they are now found even within urban greenspace, such as parks and cemeteries. Scottish red and roe deer are both native to the UK.

item.name: red deer
Cervus elaphus
Cervus
Cervidae
item.note: Large deer with dark, red-brown fur, paler rump and tail, and branching antlers. Native to the UK. Red deer are now considered a species group rather than a single species, one prevalent throughout Europe that likely originated in Asia. The male is called a stag or hart and the female a hind. Hunted and farmed for meat (venison), hair, hide, and antlers, they may also be found in deer parks. Scottish red and roe deer are both native to the UK, and European fallow deer are believed to the have been introduced by the Normans--all three species would have been extant in Mitford's time.

item.name: roe deer
Capreolus capreolus
Capreolus
Cervidae
item.note: The most common deer in the UK, a medium-sized animal with light red-brown fur, paler rump and tail, and branching antlers. Native to the UK. Common throughout Eurasia and considered part of a different genus than red or fallow deer. The male is called a buck and the female a doe. Hunted and farmed for meat (venison), hair, hide, and antlers, they may also be kept in deer parks. An adaptable species that can survive on smaller tracts of woodland, they are now found even within urban greenspace, such as parks and cemeteries. Scottish red and roe deer are both native to the UK.

item.name: dog
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: First animal species to be domesticated, before the developmment of farming, by hunter-gatherers more than fifteen thousand years ago. Descended from an ancient, now-extinct wolf species. Modern dog breeds were codified beginning in the late 19th century, with the rise of dog shows and set breed standards. Before that time, dogs were classified by appearance or function and any such may now be considered landrace, traditional, or heritage breeds. More than 50 named dog breeds originated in the UK. Breeds extant during the first half of the nineteenth century include: many terrier breeds in a range of sizes and coat types, originally bred to hunt vermin; several hounds, hunting dogs used to track or chase prey, such as the scenthounds (bloodhounds, harriers, fox hounds) and the sighthounds (greyhound, Irish Wolfhound, Scottish deerhound); mastiffs such as the English bulldog, Bullmastiff and English mastiff, used in blood sports and as guard dogs; sporting dogs used in bird hunting, such as setters and pointers; and many spaniels, including the Cavalier King Charles, Clumber, Sussex, English springer and English cocker spaniels. Now-extinct predecessor breeds include: Staghound, Buckhound, Talbot hound, Old English Bulldog, Norfolk and Tweed water spaniels, Black and Tan terrier, Cumberland sheepdog, English cur or drover's dog, Curley-coated retriever, English water spaniel, and English white terrier. Most so-called extinct breeds actually contributed bloodlines subsumed by later breeds.

item.name: donkey
Equus africanus asinus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: Domestic animal descended from the African wild ass, mostly used as draught or pack animals. In the UK, used as recreational mounts at seaside resorts. Spread throughout the Roman empire. Before the 1780s, called asses; the term may have changed to avoid vulgar connotations with similar-sounding terms like arse.

item.name: dove
Columbidae
Streptopelia
Columbidae
item.note: During the 19th century, four types of doves and pigeons were found in Britain: the stock dove, the rock dove, or feral species of the domestic pigeon, and the turtle dove, as well as the wood pigeon. Domesticated pigeons such as carrier, homing, and racing pigeons are species of the rock dove. In Britain, the wood pigeon is hunted as a game bird and domesticated pigeons were also used as food. In the ancient world, doves were associated with goddesses of love, sexuality, and maternity, such as Inanna Ishtar and Aphrodite. Doves carry symbolic significance in both the Old and New Testaments of the Hebrew Bible: in Genesis in the story of Noah and the ark as a symbol of peace and deliverance, in the Song of Songs as a term of endearment, and in Matthew as a symbol of the Holy Spirit. Doves were also acceptable burnt offerings and came to symbolize peace in early Christianity. Later literary and artistic references often draw on this association of white doves with peace, deliverance, and spiritual gifts, and are representations of the rock dove, which is highly variable in color, ranging from white to shades of grey and pale brown.

item.name: dragonfly
item.note: Predatory flying insect common to wetlands in temperate climates such as the UK. Part of an order (Odonata) that also includes damselflies. In the UK, there are 36 dragonfly species (Anisoptera) and 21 damselflies (Zygoptera).

item.name: wild duck
mallard
Anas platyrhynchos
Anas
Anatidae
item.note: Large dabbling duck with yellow-orange bill and dark blue and white wing tips, native to Eurasia, North Africa, and North America. Females are shades of brown, and males have a green head, purplish breast, and grey body. This wild species is the ancestor of most domestic ducks. They are the most commonly-hunted duck and have been a food source since ancient times. Mitford generally uses the term wild duck rather than mallard.

item.name: earwig
Forficula auricularia
Forficula
Dermaptera
item.note: Dark brown crawling insect with back pincers and lighter brown legs and folded leathery wing cases which were thought to resemble human ears. Hide in dark and damp places such as under rocks, flowerpots, and tree bark. Generally harmless, they can be considered pests since they feed on some flowering plants and pantry foodstuffs; however, they are also beneficial in gardens in that they eat destructive smaller insects such as greenfly that attack plants.

item.name: European ferret
Mustela putorius
Mustela
Mustelidae
item.note: Carnivorous mammal native to Eurasia, North Africa, and the UK. Shorter and stouter than related species like weasels or stoats, it is dark brown with a dark mask and lighter underbelly and defends its territory by spraying a malodorous liquid. Domesticated for hunting vermin and hunted for pelts. In 18th and 19th century England, Scotland and Wales, were eradicated by gamekeepers and bounty hunters, who believed them to be a nuisance animal dangerous to poultry stock. Traditionally hunted in Britain in spring with mixed packs of dogs.

item.name: glow-worm
Lampyris noctiluca
Lampyris
Lampyridae
item.note: A nocturnal beetle found throughout Europe and Asia, a member of the bioluminescent family of insects commonly called lightning bugs or fireflies. The female forms are wingless, and thus became known as worms. Found in old-growth meadows, verges, hedgerows, and heaths, peaking in June and July. A favorite subject for poets from at least the early-modern period; in Mitford's time, a common subject, particularly for sonnets, by authors who include Charlotte Smith, Anna Maria Porter, William Wordsworth, and John Clare.

item.name: goat
Capra hircus
Capra
Bovidae
item.note: Domestic grazing animals kept for their milk, meat, and skins. One of the earliest domesticated animals, descended from the wild goat found in Eastern Europe and in Southwest Asia. Males are called billygoats and females nannygoats.

item.name: golden beetle
Coccinella
Coccinella septempunctata
Coccinellidae
item.note: Despite the common name, likely the common red ladybird.

item.name: goose
Anser anser domesticus
Anser
Anatidae
item.note: Large domestic waterfowl raised as poultry. Kept for their eggs, meat, and feathers, they may also be used as guard or watch animals. One of the earliest domesticated birds. In Europe, domestic breeds descend from the wild greylag goose.

item.name: grasshopper
Orthoptera
item.note: Insect of the order of Orthoptera with large head, chewing mouthparts, and large hind legs for jumping. Fourteen types of grasshoppers and groundhoppers are found in the UK. The most common are the woodland, common green, field, meadow, and rufous grasshoppers. Symbolic of laziness and lack of prudence and foresight in Aesop's fable, The Grasshopper and the Ant. Mitford generally uses the simple term grasshopper.

item.name: greyhound
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: A sighthound originally bred for coursing game using their acute vision, agility, and speed. Later employed as a sporting dog for racing. A tall, shorted-haired slender dog with long muzzle, legs and tail, and a characteristic S-shaped body. May have a variety of coat colors including blue (grey), white, black, red, light tan (fawn) or black; and may also have patterned markings such as spots or brindle coats. Traditionally leashed in pairs for coursing and in groups of three for other types of hunting. English greyhouds may have been imported into Europe and the UK with the Romans. The Webbs bred greyhounds and coursed hares with them with the Mitfords. The Mitford family owned many greyhounds, including May-Fly, Mossy, and Miranda.

item.name: domestic guineafowl
Numida meleagris
Numida
Numididae
item.note: The helmeted guineafowl, native to subSaharan Africa, is also raised domestically as a game bird for meat and eggs. Males are called roosters and females are called hens.

item.name: brown hare
Lepus europaeus
Lepus
Leporidae
item.note: Hares and jackrabbits are wild members of the rabbit family. Brown hares are small, furry mammals with golden brown fur with white underbellies and tails and black-tipped ears. They have longer ears and more powerful legs than European rabbits and live alone or in pairs, rather than in groups. Thought to be introduced into Britain from Eurasia with the Romans or earlier.

item.name: hornet
Vespa crabro
Vespa
Vespidae
item.note: Large nesting wasp native to Eurasia and southern England, transported into North America in the nineteenth century. Also called yellowjackets.

item.name: horse
Equus ferus caballus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: Domesticated horse; different breeds are all considered of the same species. There are seventeen breeds of horses and ponies considered native to the UK, including the English thoroughbred, a racing and riding breed descended from Arabian stock; the Hackney, a trotter; and Clydesdales and Shires, bred for heavy pulling and farm work. The stud book for UK horses is kept by Weatherbys.

item.name: common kingfisher
Alcedo atthis
Alcedo
Alcedinidae
item.note: Small blue and orange bird with a large head pointed beak; frequents riparian areas and feeds on small fish and other invertebrates. Widely distributed across Eurasia and North Africa.

item.name: lark
item.note: In the UK, the lark family includes the woodlark, the skylark, and the shore lark. In Britain, the term lark conventionally refers to the skylark. Because of its habit of singing early in the morning, proverbial for early rising, and symbolic of happiness.

item.name: long-tailed wren
Spelaeornis
Spelaeornis chocolatinus
Timaliidae
item.note: The Naga wren-babbler or long-tailed wren-babbler (Spelaeornis chocolatinus), a bird species in the family Timaliidae.

item.name: mongrel dog
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: Term used in the UK for mixed or indeterminate breed dogs.

item.name: Newfoundland dog
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: Large, muscular working dog with a thick coat and webbed feet. Developed in eastern Canada to assist fishermen, they are genetically related to Irish water spaniels, Labrador retrievers, and Curly-Coated retrievers. Landseer or European Continental Type dogs with black and white coats, named for the English artist, also exist, and may be a separate breed. Sweet-tempered and loyal, they good with children and became known as nanny dogs. Nana, from Barrie's Peter Pan, was based on a black and white Landseer-type dog owned by Barrie.

item.name: nightingale
Luscinia megarhynchos
Luscinia
Muscicapidae
item.note: A medium-sized migratory songbird, brown above and beige or whitish below, native to Eurasia and overwintering in sub-saharan Africa. Best known for its beautiful and powerful song. Prefers habitats of coppiced woods and scrubland. Great Britain represents the nothernmost extent of its range. Became proverbial for a person with a melodious speaking voice or with an extraordinary singing voice.

item.name: oxen
Bos taurus
Bos
Bovidae
item.note: Large, domesticated grazing animals, often castrated bullocks of larger cattle breeds such as Sussex. Called ox and oxen when trained as draught animals to pull carts or plows. Usually yoked to work in pairs.

item.name: grey partridge
Phasianidae
perdix
Perdix perdix
item.note: Medium-sized plump grey game bird, smaller than a pheasant and larger than a quail. Native to Eurasia and the UK; has naturalized throughout North America. A nonmigratory bird that breeds on farmland, it is currently threatened in the UK, while populations remain healthy elsewhere.

item.name: peacock
Pavo cristatus
Pavo
Phasianidae
item.note: Native to the Indian subcontinent, widely introduced as domestic birds elsewhere. In the 19th century, kept in zoos and menageries as well as living ornaments to large gardens and estates. Domestic birds may be raised for meat, and their shed tailfeathers are prized for decorative uses. Omnivorous foragers that roost at night, feral birds can adapt to human habitation, roosting on buildings and foraging discarded food and other refuse. Males are known as peacocks and females as peahens, although both are commonly referred to as peacocks.

item.name: pheasant
Phasianus colchicus
Phasianus
Phasianidae
item.note: Large long-tailed game bird, native to Asia and with populations elsewhere naturalized as well as raised for hunting. The males are brightly-colored, with green heads, while the females are drab. Hybridization has bred types in a variety of colors. Pheasants, likely from the Caucasus, were naturalized in Britain by at least 1050 AD, and may have arrived earlier, with the Romans. The ring-necked variety was reintroduced in the 18th century. In the UK, the birds are hunted by traditional driven-shoot methods, employing beaters, and rough-shoot methods; both methods rely on gun dogs to flush and retrieve the birds.

item.name: domestic pig
Sus domesticus
Sus
Suidae
item.note: Large omnivorous domestic animal kept as livestock primarily for meat, but pig's bristles and hide are also used. Likely domesticated from wild boar in three separate areas: first in the Near East and China and later in Europe. By the 19th century, native UK breeds included: Tamworth, Large White, Large Black, British Lop, Berkshire, and Oxford Sandy and Black. The Berkshire is considered the oldest British breed; it's a stocky, medium-sized black pig with white patches and legs. The Oxford Sandy and Black developed in Oxfordshire in the 18th century; it's a medium-sized pig with reddish, sandy-colored skin and black patches.

item.name: pony
Equus ferus caballus
Equus
Equidae
item.note: Small breeds of horse, often with stocky and heavy body types with round heads and shorter legs as well as thicker manes and tails. In the 19th century, used for pulling light vehicles, as mounts for women and children, They were also used as ack animals, such as the pit ponies used in British mining, bred from Hills and Dales ponies of the North of England. So-called polo ponies are usually standard-sized horses. There are seventeen breeds of horses and ponies considered native to the UK, including the Shetland pony.

item.name: pug
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: Companion animal bred in China and popularized in European courts from the 16th century and later by Queen Victoria. Small dog with a wrinkly, short-haired coat, distinctive short muzzle, and curly tail. They are mostly light brown or red (fawn or apricot) with black markings. Until the 1860s, when more compact, shorter-legged Chinese pugs were imported, English pugs were longer, leaner, and less stocky. European pugs may have been bred with another popular royal lapdog breed, the King Charles spaniel, which contributed to the shorter muzzles of that breed. A fictional pug name Daphne appears in one of the Mitford's stories; this dog is described as a particularly ugly, noisy pug, that barked at every body that came into the house, and bit at most.

item.name: rabbit
Oryctolagus cuniculus
Oryctolagus
Leporidae
item.note: Small, grey-brown furry mammal that lives in groups in networks of underground burrows. Same species as domesticated rabbits, and raised for meat, fur, and as companion animals. Traditionally the fur has been felted for hats as well as used to line garments. The meat was an important staple in the diet of the poorer classes, purchased, hunted or trapped, sometimes in violation of game and enclosure laws enacted from the 18th century forward. Prefer grasslands with nearby treelines or hedges. Native to the Iberian peninsula and southern France, but has been widely introduced elsewhere. UK rabbits are believed to have come with the Normans and populations increased during the eighteenth-century with changing agricultural methods such as predator control and field crop farming.

item.name: black rat
Rattus rattus
Rattus
Muridae
item.note: Medium-sized black to light brown rodent with a lighter underside and a scaly tail, an omnivorous arboreal rat that prefers dry habitats and so is well-adapted to pre-industrial human settings, including wood and thatched buildings. The most common rat in Europe and North America from the Roman conquest to the eighteenth century, likely originiating in southeast Asia. Displaced by the larger brown rat through increased urbanization, industrialization, and pest control. Now nearly eradicated in the UK.

item.name: brown rat
Rattus norvegicus
Rattus
Muridae
item.note: Large grey-brown rodent with a scaly tail, an omnivorous burrowing rat that prefers damp habitats and so is well-adapted to human habitation since the Industrial Revolution, including brick and tile buildings and sewers. The most common rat in Europe and North America, likely originiating in north or central Asia. Called the Norway rat or the Hanover rat from erroneous beliefs about their origin outside the UK. Written evidence exists of their presence in Europe by the 1550s and in the UK by the early eighteenth century, becoming widespread by the early 19th century. Fancy (pet) rats and laboratory rats are domesticated subspecies of this wild rat.

item.name: robin redbreast
Erithacus rubecula
Erithacus
Muscicapidae
item.note: Small songbird, native to Europe, now considered a type of Old World flycatcher. In Mitford's time, believed to be part of the thrush family, along with nightingales. Not to be confused with the American robin, a new World thrush, this bird is sometimes referred to as an English robin in North America. Frequently referenced in British folk tales and popular culture, the bird became associated with the Christmas holiday in the mid-nineteenth century. The bird's name derives from the male forename Robin or Robert, which led to nicknames of Bob and Bobby. Robins in Great Britain are generally less wary of humans than their counterparts in continental Europe. Mitford calls the tame robins she feeds her bobbies.

item.name: rock dove
pigeon
Columba livia
Columba
Columbidae
item.note: Very common and widely-distributed dove, originally native to Eurasia and North Africa. Feral rock doves are pale grey with an iridescent green neck and two black bars on their wings. Domesticated pigeons, including racing, homing and carrier pigeons, as well as those raised for food, are all part of the rock dove family. Highly variable in color, ranging from white to pale grey and brown, with a white rump. Literary and artistic representations of doves are most often white rock doves.

item.name: rook
Corvus frugilegus
Corvus
Corvidae
item.note: Large member of the crow family, with a distinctive light-colored bill and featherless area on the face; roosts at the tops of trees in large social groups. Historically, British farmers have considered them nuisances, as they make holes while foraging in agricultural fields and elsewhere for seeds and ground-based insects like grubs.

item.name: sheep
Ovis aries
Ovis
Bovidae
item.note: Domesticated grazing animals kept as livestock for their fleece and milk, and as meat. One of the earliest domesticated animals, descended from the mouflon of Europe and Asia. The UK continues to be a center of sheep production, as it was in the 19th century and earlier. Sheep feature in pastoral art and literature, fables and nursery rhymes, as well as in ancient world mythology and Abrahamic religions.

item.name: shore lark
Eremophila alpestris
Eremophila
Alaudidae
item.note: Lark native to northern Eurasia and North America; also known as the horned lark. Prefers open fields as well as seashores.

item.name: skylark
Alauda arvensis
Alauda
Alaudidae
item.note: Eurasian songbird with gray-brown plumage above and whitish plumage beneath. Famous for its melodius warbling song while in flight, and symbolically associated with the passionate enthusiasm of love and lovers. Percy Shelley's poem To a Skylark appeared in 1820.

item.name: grass snake
Natrix
Natrix natrix
Colubridae
item.note: Native to Eurasia, including the UK semi-aquatic non-venomous colubrid snake. Often found near water and feeds on amphibians.

item.name: spaniel
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: In Mitford's time, spaniels were classified as land or water types, and as springer (larger) and cocker (smaller) types, although springers and cockers may have come from the same litter. They are gun dogs bred to flush or spring game birds. They were also used to hunt rabbits, sometimes alongside greyhounds. They may have solid or parti-colored coats in black, liver, red, or golden, with tan masking and trim, roan patching, or ticked spots. The most common color is liver (dark brown/chocolate) and white. The Sussex spaniel, first recorded in 1795, is a stocky spaniel with a distinctive golden-brown colored coat and hazel eyes. The spaniel, Flush, gifted by Mitford to Elizabeth Barrett Browning, had a golden-brown coat and hazel eyes, as described in her poem To Flush, My Dog. Molly was a white spaniel with a wavy coat, perhaps with water spaniel ancestry. The Mitfords raised and bred spaniels kept as companion animals and for coursing; these included several dogs named Flush. Mitford records that one brown spaniel anmed Flush accompanied her father into a Reading theatre: Flush, with his paws on the front of the box, his large earnest eyes fixed on the actors, and his long silky ears brought forward on either side of his face, as is the custom of those intelligent dogs on great occasions, looked and listened all through the piece with a sedate fixity of attention, which greatly endangered the gravity of the persons on the stage.

item.name: squirrel
Sciurus vulgaris
Sciurus
Sciuridae
item.note: Tree squirrel with tufted ears native to Europe, Asia, and the UK. North American red squirrels are pine squirrels, genus Tamiasciurus, a different genus and species.

item.name: stock dove
Columba oenas
Columba
Columbidae
item.note: Eurasian dove, pale grey above and below with a pinkish neck and iridescent green neck band, common in the UK. Similar in size and shape to the rock dove, but lacking a white rump.

item.name: mute swan
Cygnus olor
Cygnus
Anatidae
item.note: The mute swan, a large white waterbird with a distinctive orange-red and black knobbed beak, is a Eurasian species prevalent across Europe and the UK. Associated with Apollo and Venus in classical mythology. Symbolic of purity, because of their color; and faithful love, since swans are believed to grieve for the loss or death of a mate or cygnet. Mythologized as singing beautifully before their death, and thus, identified with extraordinary singers or poets; for example, referring to Shakespeare as the swan of Avon.

item.name: terrier
Canis familiaris
Canis
Canidae
item.note: In the 19th century, terriers were categorized as short- or long-legged, as well as categorized informally by function, such as rat terrier or fox terrier. UK terrier breeds appear in a range of sizes and coat types, and were originally bred to be fearless and agile in order hunt vermin (rats, foxes) underground. Terriers were used in blood sports such as rat-catching. Terriers and bulldog-terrier mixes were also used in dogfighting. Two notable heritage breeds, now extinct, include the black-and-tan terrier and the English white terrier. A terrer named Viper appears in one of Mitford's stories.

item.name: brown trout
Salmo trutta
Salmo
Salmonidae
item.note: The only trout native to the UK, their native range extends from Norway in the north, west to Iceland and east to the Aral Sea. Varieties include sea-run forms, which return to fresh water to spawn; river trout, and lake trout. British angling works refer to this species. Other species of trout were not introduced into the UK until the late 19th century.

item.name: turkey
Meleagris gallopavo domesticus
Meleagris
Phasianidae
item.note: Large domestic fowl raised as poultry. Breeds descend from a subspecies from central Mexico, domesticated by ancient Mesoamericans and imported by the Spanish into Europe. Brought to England in the 16th century and imported back to North America with British colonization. Remained a rare, luxury holiday meat in the UK until the 20th century; goose or beef were more common.

item.name: turtle dove
Streptopelia turtur
Streptopelia
Columbidae
item.note: Small, pale brown and gray migratory member of the dove and pigeon family. Once common throughout Europe and the Middle East and wintering in southern Africa, it is now an endangered species in the UK and elsewhere. This bird is known for its mournful voice, and is therefore associated with love and loss. Mentioned in both the Old and New Testaments, in early-modern Europe the bird became mythologized as the partner of the phoenix.

item.name: woodpigeon
Columba palumbus
Columba
Columbidae
item.note: The most common member of the dove and pigeon family in Britain, a large grey pigeon with a pinkish breast and distinctive white patches on its neck and wings.

item.name: woodlark
Lullula arborea
Lullula
Alaudidae
item.note: Eurasian lark with distinctive black and yellow facial markings. Prefers open clearings near pine forest and heathland.

item.name: crested wren
Regulus regulus
Regulus
Regulidae
item.note: Tiny olive-green songbird whose head has a distinctive yellow or orange stripe, frequents woodlands and gardens. Called the crested wren in Mitford's time and earlier, although this bird is not a member of the wren family, but is from the family of kinglets and firecrests. Despite its tiny size, considered the king of the birds in European folklore.

item.name: acacia
Robinia pseudoacacia
Robinia
Fabaceae
item.note: Mitford likely refers to the false acacia or black locust, a thorny hardwood tree in the pea family, bearing white flower clusters, native to the Eastern US and imported into the UK in the 17th century. In Mitford's time the true acacia, also known as the Egyptian acacia (acacia nilotica), was thought to be a relative of the mimosa or sensitive plant.

item.name: winter aconite
Eranthis hyemalis
Eranthis
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Tuberous, low-growing yellow flowering plant native to Europe and naturalized in the UK. One of the earliest woodland wildflowers, appearing in late winter. Unrelated to aconitum (monkshood).

item.name: alder
Alnus glutinosa
Alnus
Betulaceae
item.note: Group of deciduous trees and shrubs with serrated leaves and woody catkins, generally found in riparian and marshy areas. Native to Europe and the UK. Alder is a relatively lightweight hardwood, used in furniture making, and the bark and wood contain tannins used to tan leather. The rot-resistant wood was also traditionally used for building foundations and making gunpowder.

item.name: anemone
Anemone
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Mitford may refer to the wood anemone (Anemone nemorosa), an early-spring flowering plant, native to Europe. Common names include wood anemone, windflower, thimbleweed, and smell fox, an allusion to the musky smell of the leaves. However, she may also refer to one of the cultivated varieties not native to England, such as the poppy anemone (Anemone coronaria), which is native to the Mediterranean region but was cultivated elsewhere in Europe beginning in the eighteenth century. Unlike the wood anemone, the poppy anemone appears in bright shades of red and blue.

item.name: apple tree
Malus domestica
Malus
‎Rosaceae
item.note: Deciduous tree producing showy pink and white flowers and then firm round pomes, usually red and yellow-green fruit. Cultivated varieties developed from wild trees in Central Asia, and have likely been domesticated for at least four thousand years. Before the invention of refrigeration, the fruit was important for its ability to be dried, to overwinter in cold storage and to produce fermented cider. While the apple appears in many mythological and religious traditions as a mystical or forbidden object, as in the forbidden Edenic fruit in the Old Testament, the term generally referred to any edible or non-native fruit, and did not necessarily indicate fruits of the genus Malus. There are currently more than 7,000 apple cultivars and the University of Reading, in Berkshire, is responsible for the UK national apple database. Mitford mentions at least three varieties: golden rennet or Golden Reinette also known as the English pippin, a golden-yellow apple, streaked red-orange; russetting types, apples whose smooth skin is covered all or in part by rougher brown skin, thought to have more nutty and aromatic flavors than non-russeting types and used in cider making; and a crumplingtype; an underdeveloped or deformed apple that shrivels on the tree.

item.name: apricot
Prunus armeniaca
Prunus
Prunus
item.note: Flowering fruit tree of the plum family, believed to be native to Asia, although it has been cultivated for its fruit across Eurasia since antiquity. Formerly thought to be introduced into Greece from Armenia. Produces showy white-pink flowers that develop pinkish-yellow fleshy stone fruits. The fruits as well as the almond-like seeds are edible, and the fruits may be made into jams and jellies, syrups and cordials, and desserts.

item.name: arum
Arum maculatum
Arum
Araceae
item.note: The so-called arum lily is a native European woodland plant, not a true lily. It bears purple-spotted leaves and an inconspicuous flower stalk hidden within a spathe or leaf-like hood. The stalk later develops poisonous red berries. In Britain, plant is also called the cuckoo pint, a euphemistic reference to male genitalia that dates from Culpeper's 17th century herbal; other common names also refer to human genitalia. Arum italicum or Italian lords-and-ladies is also native to the UK.

item.name: ash
Fraxinus excelsior
Fraxinus
Oleaceae
item.note: Deciduous tree with compound leaves, black leaf buds, inconspicuous purple-red flower clusters, and large and conspicuous winged seeds. Native to Eurasia, North Africa, and the UK. One of the most common trees in the UK, often found with oak and elm, although it has been affected recently by ash dieback. A tough hardwood with a straight grain, used for making furniture as well as tool handles, hockey sticks, walking sticks, and oars. Also used to make the bodies of carriages and early motor cars.

item.name: asparagus
Asparagus officinalis
Asparagus
Asparagaceae
item.note: Flowering perrenial plant whose young shoots are cultivated as a vegetable. Native to Eurasia, the subspecies Asparagus officinalis subsp. prostratus is believed to be native to coastal western Europe, north Ireland, and Great Britain.

item.name: auricula
Primula
Primula auricula
Primulaceae
item.note: Wild member of the primrose family, bearing in spring yellow flowerets above a rosette of dark green leaves, native to the mountains of Central Europe. Garden primroses are a hybridized species developed as a cross between P. auricula and P. hirsuta. A popular garden plant in 18th-century Britain.

item.name: azalea
Rhododendron
Ericaceae
item.note: Flowering shrub carrying abundantly showy red, pink, or white blooms in spring, related to rhododendrons. Grow in the understory of woodlands, and have been hybridized as garden shrubs for hundreds of years. Native to Eurasia and North America. Introduced to the UK in the 19th century as a garden ornamental, it is now considered an invasive species.

item.name: bay
Laurus nobilis
Laurus
Lauraceae
item.note: Small evergreen tree with aromatic leaves, native to the Mediterranean and grown in the UK as a garden shrub. The bay leaf is be used as a food seasoning. In versions of the myth of Apollo and Daphne, Gaia turns Daphne into a laurel tree. Synonymous with the laurel in Greco-Roman culture, associated with the priestess of Apollo, the Pythia, and later, Roman Emperors. Used to make victory crowns and wreaths and therefore symbolic of honor and achievement. Mentioned in Psalm 37, verse 36 quoted in the Book of Common Prayer: I myself have seen the ungodly in great power; and flourishing like a green bay-tree.

item.name: common bean
Phaseolus
Fabaceae
item.note: Also called the green bean, the common bean is a member of a large family of herbaceous flowering plants whose seeds or legumes, and pods, are cultivated and consumed by humans and animals. Wild types are twining, as are some cultivated types, while others grow as low rounded clumps. A spring-flowering plant with white, pink, or purple scented blooms. Fava or >broad beans are also historically cultivated in England. The OED suggests that fields of this bean are those commonly mentioned in literature as fragrant.

item.name: broad bean
Vicia fabia
Vicia
Fabaceae
item.note: Member of the large family of herbaceous flowering plants whose seeds or legumes, and pods, are cultivated and consumed by humans and animals. Native to the Mediterranean, the plants form an erect plant with grey-green leaves carrying white flowers with a purple-black spot; it then develops a leathery pod containing several large oval edible seeds. Historically, the broad (or fava) bean was commonly cultivated in England in Mitford's time, as was the common bean.

item.name: beech
Fagus
Fagaceae
Fagus sylvatica
item.note: A genus of deciduous trees, native to temperate Europe, Asia and North America. Mitford likely refers to the European beech (Fagus sylvatica) which is considered native to the southern UK and introduced elsewhere for tall hedging and plantations, particularly after the eighteenth century. More recently, research suggests the beech was introduced into England around 4,000 B.C. and so is non-native. Beech woods are densely canopied with floors suitable only for shade-loving understory plants such as bluebells. The bark is smooth and light grey and the tree bears inconspicuous flowers and catkins that develop into husk-enclosed nuts that are bitter but edible. The nuts and bark are high in tannins, used to tan leather, and the trees produce a fine-grained medium-weight wood used for indoor flooring, staircases, and small furniture. It also makes good firewood, as well as wood pulp for papermaking.

item.name: beetroot
Beta vulgaris
Caryophyllales
Amaranthaceae
item.note: Garden plant grown primarily for its edible roots, but also for its edible leaves, sometimes known as chard or beet greens. Cultivated in the ancient world for food and for medicinal use. Other important subspecies are sugar beet, grown to make table sugar, and mangelwurzel, an animal fodder crop.

item.name: weeping birch
Betula pendula
Betula
Betulaceae
item.note: Medium-sized birch tree with white, peeling bark, triangular leaves that turn yellow before falling, and catkins in spring. Mitford uses the term weeping birch to refer to a pendulous variety of the white birch (Betula alba). A lightweight and light-colored wood used in making furniture and skis. Birch brush is used historically for racecourse jumps, the bark in tanning and traditional medicine, and wood strips for weaving small containers, baskets, and footwear.

item.name: bluebell
Hyacinthoides non-scripta
Hyacinthoides
Asparagaceae
item.note: Bulbous flowering perennial plant, native to Atlantic western Europe and the UK, and also frequently used as a garden plant. Carries fragrant violet-blue tubular flowers on a one-sided stem. In Britain, it is found in ancient woodlands, where it forms carpets of flowers in the spring, called bluebell woods. Mitford uses the terms wild hyacinth as well as bluebell for this plant. She uses the term harebell to refer to the more papery bell-flowered campanulas. In a letter to Mrs. Hoare, Mitford explains the different terms: The Wild Hyacinth, my dear Mrs. Hoare, differs much from the flower which we call the harebell in England: a small campanula, bearing two or three exquisite, thin, bell-like papery flowers (you can hear them rustle when shaken) on a very thin and fragile stalk, growing among wild thyme, and under heather, in the month of August. There is a white variety cultivated in gardens, but no pink one. I have heard both the harebell and the wild hyacinth called blue-bells.

item.name: fern
Pteridium aquilinum
Pteridium
Dennstaedtiaceae
item.note: A genus of large, sturdy ferns, common throughout the world. It may be the most adaptable and oldest group of ferns. Commonly found on moorlands and hillsides and may form dense thickets of fronds, spread through its creeping roots. In the UK, moorland types are called moorland scrub. Traditionally gathered for use in leather tanning, soap- and glass-making, and for use as livestock bedding. Today, it may be seen as a threat to biodiversity, as its spread can elbow out other ground-cover plants upon which animals and other plants depend, and decrease the size of open moorlands.

item.name: bramble
Rubus fruticosus
Rubus
Rosaceae
item.note: In the UK, generally refers to the common blackberry, a prickly shrub with arching branches, bearing small white flowers followed by aggregate red or black fruits. The general term may also refer to other prickly shrubs, such as dog-roses, or to the fruit of the blackberry.

item.name: briar
item.note: Historically used to refer to any thorny shrub, including the bramble, or common blackberry, and the wild rose or dog-rose. Now mainly used to refer to the latter; Mitford may use the term synonymously with wild rose, since she uses the term bramble elsewhere.

item.name: broom
Cytisus
Cytisus scoparius
Fabaceae
item.note: Perennial flowering shrub, member of the legume or pea family, native to Europe and the UK. Grows in meadows and heathland and propagates itself through pea-like seedpods. Symbolizes humility and neatness in floriography, because of its association with the housekeeping implement. It was common to include a decorated bundle of broom at weddings.

item.name: common buttercup
Ranunculus acris
Ranunculus
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Perennial wildflower of medium height with small, shiny yellow flowers with prominent green or yellow sepals. Native to Eurasia but widely naturalized elsewhere.

item.name: cabbage
Brassica oleracea
Brassica
Brassicaceae
item.note: Cultivated variety of Brassica oleracea, grows as dense-leaved round heads. Likely descended from wild varieties native to the Mediterranean region and cultivated in the ancient world. An important part of the European and British diet by the early medieval period.

item.name: red cabbage
Brassica
Brassica oleracea
Brassicaceae
item.note: Edible arden plant, related to the green cabbage whose leaves are dark red-purple, depending on the acidity of the soil. Mitford jokingly compares herself to one in her letter to Elford of 14 May 1819 (because she is round and red). Keeps well over winter and is eaten raw or cooked.

item.name: campanula
Campanula
Campanulaceae
item.note: General term used for a large genus of plants with white or blue bell-shaped flowers, including the harebell. Mitford may use this term for Canterbury bells (Campanula medium), a taller bellflower than the harebell, native to southern Europe but cultivated as a garden plant in Britain.

item.name: carnation
Dianthus Caryophyllus
Dianthus
Caryophyllaceae
item.note: Cultivated variety of the clove or clove-pink. Scentless types are used for men's buttonholes.

item.name: celery
Apium graveolens
Apium
Apiaceae
item.note: Both wild celery and the cultivated variety are the same species. Wild varieties grow in wetlands and are most noticeable for their parsley-like leaves and white flower stalk. Cultivated varieties are grown for their fibrous stalks and their seeds, which are used as a spice. It is thought to be native to the Mediterranean region, and has been cultivated since antiquity, in winter and early spring. Further hybridization by the 19th century had extended the growing season, and celery became an increasing important raw and cooked vegetable in British, American and European cuisines.

item.name: bird-cherry
Prunus padus
Prunus
Rosaceae
item.note: Large deciduous shrub native to Eurasia and the UK, smaller than the wild cherry and with fruit that is more tart and oval leaves that are less tart. Carries white flower clusters that develop into black fruits. Few European culinary uses, although the tree is planted as a flowering garden ornamental.

item.name: wild cherry
Prunus avium
Prunus
Rosaceae
item.note: Deciduous hardwood fruit tree, native to Eurasia and the UK. Deeply veined oval leaves with pink-white flower clusters that develop bright red fruit clusters, which are actually a sweet pulpy drupe with a seed or pit. A valuable reddish hardwood much used in furniture and musical instrument making in the 18th and 19th century. The fruit is used in making jellies and jams, syrups and cordials, and desserts. As color descriptor, often associated with women's beauty, as in cherry-cheeked or cherry-lipped.

item.name: China Aster
Callistephus chinensis
Callistephus
Asteraceae
item.note: An annual flowering plant native to China and Korea, with single or double daisy-like flowers in white, pink, or purple; unrelated to the perennial aster. Grown as a garden plant and cut flower.

item.name: chrysanthemum
Chrysanthemum indicum
Chrysanthemum
Asteraceae
item.note: Semi-hardy fall-flowering perennial native to East Asia and to Northeastern Europe. Hybridized in China from the 15th century B.C. and in Japan from the 8th century; the flower has accumulated many symbolic meanings throughout Asian countries over time. Introduced into Europe and the UK and hybridized from the 17th century. Although thousands of hybrids exist, the plants may generally be categorized as garden hardy and exhibition or florist's types.

item.name: gum cistus
Cistus ladanifer
Cistus
Cistaceae
item.note: Evergreen shrub bearing papery white flowers with a dark red spot at the base of each petal.
